item.title: Israel bombs Rafah alleging that Hamas attacked military unit
item.description: Israel launched a series of air strikes against the city of Rafah, in the Gaza Strip, after accusing Hamas of attacking a military engineering unit, security sources cited by the Israeli press said yesterday. Pending an official statement from the Israel Defense Forces and the Islamist group Hamas, military sources confirmed to the Israeli website Walla and the Times of Israel that air and ground attacks had been carried out in Rafah, claiming that it was a response to an attack on an Israeli military excavator tasked with destroying the Islamist organization's tunnels. Although there is still no official information about the existence of deaths or injuries, Israeli military sources told Israeli television that two alleged Hamas militants were killed. It is also unknown whether this crossfire could jeopardize the ceasefire that came into force on October 10, but the Israeli Minister of National Security, Itamar Ben Givr, has already urged the Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, to resume the offensive against the Gaza Strip. “I ask the Prime Minister to order the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) to fully resume fighting in the Gaza Strip with all its personnel,” said the minister, who was convicted in the past for inciting hatred against Palestinians, vandalism and support for terrorism. According to a source from Hamas' armed wing, the group had launched an operation in Rafah to eliminate the leader of the rival militia, known as 'Popular Forces', Yasser Abu Shabab. However, Israeli soldiers intervened to support Shabab, which resulted in crossfire and caused the Israeli excavator to explode. The United States warned on Saturday that it had “credible information” about an “imminent attack” by Hamas against Palestinian civilians, in a “clear violation” of the ceasefire. Chaos installed Yesterday morning, the Islamist group rejected the accusation and blamed Israel for arming and financing other militias, which, it said, carried out “murders, kidnappings, robberies of humanitarian aid trucks and robberies against civilians”. According to Hamas, its members in Gaza are, “with broad civil and popular support”, pursuing these gangs and holding them accountable “according to clear legal mechanisms, to protect citizens and preserve public and private property”. Just one day after the ceasefire, Hamas militants began cracking down on all clans and militias that allegedly collaborated with Israel during the past two years' war, including public executions of alleged collaborators, images of which went viral. The ceasefire in Gaza – proposed by the United States and agreed between Israel and Hamas – has been in force since October 10, providing for three phases: the release of hostages, the disarmament of Hamas and the gradual reconstruction of the territory, under international supervision. The second stage, centered on “demilitarization”, remains the most controversial and the one that Israel considers essential to put an end to the conflict.

item.title: Takeaway | Request for worker protection
item.description: Deputy Leong Hong Sai questions the Government about whether it has plans to legislate the status of workers on online food delivery platforms. The matter was raised by the deputy linked to the Residents, through a written interpellation published on Friday. In the document, Leong points out as a problem the fact that distributors are considered “independent workers”, but they are nevertheless subject to complying with the employer's orders, as in a traditional employment relationship. “Currently, several online food and order delivery platforms in Macau define their workers as ‘independent workers’ or ‘partners’, thus excluding them from legal labor protections,” he accused. “It is understood that some platforms allocate orders through algorithms and implement incentive schemes, preventing platform workers from enjoying the autonomy typical of traditional independent work,” he added. The deputy therefore asks the Executive to create a legal statute to ensure the labor protection of distributors. “Will authorities review existing regulations governing employment relationships to comprehensively regulate online food and parcel delivery platforms?” he asks. “Furthermore, will they make appropriate adjustments in response to changes in the labor market to promptly clarify the legal status, responsibilities and rights of both companies and platform workers?”, he asks.

item.title: Fengshen | Typhoon expected to pass 400km from Macau
item.description: Tropical cyclone Fengshen is expected to pass around 400 kilometers south of Macau on Wednesday, according to the Meteorological and Geophysical Services Directorate (DSMG). At that time, according to yesterday's forecasts, the tropical cyclone should gain strength and transform into a typhoon. “Therefore, depending on the development of Fengshen and changes in wind strength in Macau, a Tropical Storm Signal will be issued from Monday night (today)”, it was pointed out. Since yesterday, it was also predicted that the wind would begin to intensify due to “a northeast monsoon”, and authorities believed that there would be a “significant increase, with the wind reaching levels 6 to 7 on the Beaufort Scale”. Temperatures | Descent to 18 degrees From today until Wednesday, temperatures are expected to drop to 18 degrees, according to information released yesterday by the Directorate of Meteorological and Geophysical Services (DSMG). “Regarding the weather, precipitation is expected, with the minimum temperature dropping to around 18 degrees Celsius, between Monday and Wednesday (20 to 22)”, it was indicated. "Due to the significant drop in temperatures next week, and the strong wind associated with cloudy weather with precipitation, the thermal sensation of cold will be lower than the actual temperature. DSMG urges the population to pay attention to the most recent meteorological information", it was added.

item.title: Agualusa says that a bad writer will never write a good book
item.description: A bad writer “will never write a good novel using artificial intelligence”, said writer José Eduardo Agualusa this Saturday at FOLIO – Óbidos International Literary Festival, arguing that this instrument does not pose a danger to authors and may even have some potential. “I believe that a bad writer will never write a good novel using artificial intelligence”, but “perhaps a good writer will be able to write a better novel once he knows how to use this instrument”, he added. At a panel of authors in which he assured that artificial intelligence does not scare him, the Angolan writer considered that this instrument “is still used in a trivial way” by many people, but that when “if you know how to use it well, you will probably discover greater potential”. Even so, he considers that there is no danger of “writers being replaced”, because artificial intelligence “mimics, reproduces the writer’s style”, but “the imitation of the style is normally ridiculous”. In other chapters “that instrument is very useful”, he said, giving as an example the Angolan chronicle in the newspapers, which “improved a lot, because it corrects very well”. “In the case of Angola it is very clear, suddenly the chroniclers started to write better, any emergency we ask for and the weekly column comes out”. However, in the long narrative, in the novel, “the AI ​​still has a big challenge” and, even if one day it manages to write “a mediocre novel” it will have to have “someone behind it, with creativity”. Conversations on FOLIO José Eduardo Agualusa spoke at the 12th panel of FOLIO, in a conversation with Brazilian writer Giovana Madalosso, where both argued that literature is not in danger, despite movements of censorship and cancellation of writers in countries like Brazil. Because “more and more people are reading. More and more people are reading better”, said Agualusa. The FOLIO ended yesterday. This year marked the tenth year of existence with more than 460 initiatives, including more than a hundred conversations between authors and the public, 15 author tables, gatherings, seminars, book launches, concerts and prize giving.

item.title: Caritas | More than 3,500 requests for help received by the end of September
item.description: The number of support requests shows a stabilization trend in recent years. And given the lack of “very serious” poverty problems, Cáritas Macau also extended its support program to Pakistan and Bangladesh Cáritas Macau received 3,509 requests for support for the Food Bank by the end of September, the organization's secretary-general said yesterday, indicating that this year's final values ​​should not differ from those of 2024. “We expect it [in 2025] to exceed four thousand, like last year”, noted Paul Pun Chi Meng to Lusa, pointing out that, in 2024, 4,936 requests reached the humanitarian organization, which, in turn, represents a drop of 2.5 percent compared to 2023 (5,065). In an annual comparison, the first nine months of 2025 present values ​​similar to those recorded in the same period of 2023 and 2024: 3,589 and 3,596, respectively. Even so, there is a slight decline this year, which could be related to the “existence of other support resources” or “greater ease in applying for social housing”, noted Pun, implying that easier access to public housing could ease the bills at the end of the month. The program, aimed at low-income people and financed by the authorities, foresees that the Bank's support will result in food aid for a period of ten weeks, with a second request being possible within 12 months. Among non-resident workers, highlighted Paul Pun, there is also a group that uses social assistance organizations. Last Saturday, close to a thousand people received support in the form of food baskets. Aid in Pakistan and Bangladesh The secretary general of Cáritas also explained that as Macau does not face “very serious poverty” problems, the organization is supporting disadvantaged families in Bangladesh and Pakistan, providing aid to 2,100 people. Last week, Pun returned from Sylhet, a city in northeastern Bangladesh that he has visited several times since 2023, the year in which Cáritas Macau became involved in a program to “improve the health and nutrition of disadvantaged children”. With donations of around 15 thousand dollars per year, aid has already reached 400 people, said the person in charge. “We hope that, through training, in terms of care for newborns, mothers, they can achieve a better life”, pointed out the general secretary of Cáritas Macau, also noting that, on the table is the possibility of providing resources for the professional training of teenagers who dropped out of school. About a month ago, Paul Pun was also in Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan, with nearly 14 million inhabitants and which has been affected, in recent years, by several floods. Cáritas Macau's assistance to the “Informal education and development of young people and women” program, with the transfer of up to 35 thousand dollars per year (around 30 thousand euros), has already touched the lives of 1,200 children and 500 teenagers in Lahore, according to the leader of the humanitarian organization. "The children do not have schools [in these places]. They participate in this informal education program so that they have an opportunity to reach the standards and one day be able to enter school", he said. In addition to supporting the education of teenagers – “especially boys” – in areas such as IT, the program also includes skills training “by young women”. To Lusa, Paul Pun said that international assistance from Cáritas Macau arrives “via several channels”, namely through donations and the organization Good Fortune Charity Shop, the social enterprise of Cáritas Macau, which collects donated goods for charitable sale.

item.title: Justice | Portugal may send new judges to Macau
item.description: Despite having prevented Carlos Carvalho from remaining in the territory and maintaining uncertainty about the future of Rui Ribeiro, who chose to return to Portugal, the Superior Council of the Judiciary of Portugal guarantees openness to sending new magistrates to the Macao SAR The president of the Supreme Court of Justice (STJ) stated that Portugal is available, if Macau shows interest, in sending new judges. The statements were made at a time when a Portuguese magistrate is about to leave the Macao SAR. Judge Rui Ribeiro, of the Court of Second Instance, confirmed to Lusa, on the sidelines of a public event, that he will leave Macau at the end of October, bringing forward the end of the commission, which ended in May 2026. The magistrate stressed that the Macau judicial authorities “did everything” to make him change his mind, but explained that he preferred to return to Portugal now given the uncertainty regarding a possible renewal of the special license by the Superior Council of Judiciary (CSM). With the announced departure of Rui Ribeiro, only one Portuguese judge remains in the Macau courts: Jerónimo Alberto Gonçalves Santos, president of a collective court at the Base Judicial Court (TJB). The leader of the STJ, João Cura Mariano, who inherently also presides over the CSM, told journalists that, during a visit to Macau, he wanted to find out if the territory was interested in having Portuguese magistrates. “We are going to try to see what they can really convey that is useful and whether they are necessary, because if they are necessary, new judges will come”, he assured the journalists. João Cura Mariano said that this would be a “subject to discuss” in yesterday's meetings with the president of the Court of Final Instance (TUI), Song Man Lei, and with Sam Hou Fai, leader of the Macau Government and former president of the TUI. “I think it is very useful, because, being a former president of the court [Sam Hou Fai] he will be aware of the needs that exist”, said the Portuguese judge advisor. National difficulties But the president of the STJ highlighted that Portuguese justice is having “some difficulty in contributing judges”, due to the lack of qualified and experienced human resources. “Just now we removed a judge who had been here for many years and we needed him”, recalled João Cura Mariano. In 2024, the CSM rejected the stay of Portuguese TJB judge Carlos Carvalho, who had been in Macau for 16 years and had been invited by the Independent Commission for the Nomination of Judges in the territory to continue for another two years. The council did not authorize the renewal of Carlos Carvalho's special license and promoted him to judge, with placement at the Court of Appeal. Even so, João Cura Mariano assured that he was willing to help, “despite the difficulties that currently exist in Portugal in recruiting judges”. The president of the STJ highlighted the example of Timor-Leste, where there are currently “many Portuguese judges collaborating in the Timorese judicial system”, because “they are very necessary”. The judge was in Macau to participate, on Sunday, in the 13th edition of the forum that brings together presidents of the Supreme Courts of Justice of Portuguese-speaking countries and territories.

item.title: Bridges | Advisor suggests tolls and generates chorus of criticism
item.description:
On October 10th, Leong Chi Hang, member of the Consultative Council of Community Services of the Islands, suggested the introduction of toll payments on the four bridges that cross between the Macau peninsula and Taipa. The opinion sparked controversy on social media and even led a listener to call in to the morning show on Radio Macau's Chinese channel.
Councilor Leong Chi Hang, member of the Consultative Council for Community Services of the Islands, defended at a meeting of this body, on October 10th, that tolls should be paid on the four bridges that cross between the Macau peninsula and the islands. This suggestion was made during the period of interventions before the agenda of the aforementioned organization, with Leong Chi Hang, who is also vice-president of the Taipa Community Development Promotion Association, arguing that it is necessary for the Government to improve and reform the bridge management system due to frequent traffic jams in these road infrastructures. "I suggest that an electronic collection system be created with tolls on these four bridges, and the collection would be made according to different periods, vehicles. An additional fee could be added in times of greater circulation", he said. According to Leong Chi Hang, the objective of charging tolls would be to balance the flow of vehicles on the four bridges by adjusting the toll charges, as for some people the increased costs of crossing the bridge by car may make them opt more for public transport. In this way, priority will be given to public transport and more environmentally friendly travel. Fired fuse This opinion was publicized on social media during the Advisory Council meeting, especially in Facebook groups, which generated a wave of critical opinions. And the wave of protest did not stop on social media: on Friday a resident, surnamed Ma, called the morning program Forum Macau on the Chinese channel Radio Macau, criticizing this measure, arguing that, to alleviate the traffic situation on bridges, procedures for dealing with road accidents should be simplified. "I don't think [charging tolls] is a viable suggestion, as bridges are always filled with traffic and an additional charge is still being advocated. Traffic jams often occur on bridges not due to an excess of cars, but rather due to the occurrence of road accidents. Why can't we simplify procedures similar to what happens in Mainland China?", he asked. This listener argued that “if [a road accident] does not involve criminal proceedings, and it is enough to take photographs of the accident, the vehicles involved in the accident can be removed from the scene” more quickly. Ma also complained about the fact that Macau continues to maintain an outdated system for dealing with road accidents, even though the territory has recently adopted digital solutions, such as the installation of video surveillance cameras, which end up not being well used to deal with this type of cases.

item.title: AL | André Cheong promises presidency to meet expectations
item.description: At the beginning of the new legislature, deputies received “three expectations” from the Chief Executive, one of which involves “working together” with the Government, but also exercising law enforcement functions. When performing the duties of president of the Legislative Assembly, André Cheong promises to keep in mind the Chief Executive's expectations for the work of the legislative body. The statements were made by the new president of the hemicycle, in an interview with TDM's Chinese-language channels. "As president of the Legislative Assembly I feel that the weight of responsibility is greater. I will strictly comply with the provisions of the law and regulations to carry out my duties as president", stated the new president of the AL, quoted by Canal Macau. “At the same time, I will take into account the three expectations established by the Chief Executive for the new composition of the Legislative Assembly, leading the team well in legislative work and in the scope of supervision”, he added. André Cheong was elected president of the AL on Friday and had the vote of all deputies, including his own. It was the first time, at least since 2019, that a deputy was unanimously elected president. The president of the AL also intends to implement greater cooperation between the Government and the hemicycle's technicians. “For important law proposals related to the well-being of the population, the Government needs considerable preparation time”, he indicated. "We hope to encourage AL technical teams to get involved earlier in the preparatory phase of government departments. For example, preliminary technical discussions and exchanges can result in more fluid technical communication when these important bills are being analyzed by the Legislative Assembly", he pointed out. Three desires After the start of the new Legislature, last Thursday, the Chief Executive held a meeting with deputies. On this occasion, according to the official version, given that the meeting took place behind closed doors, Sam Hou Fai told the legislators that he has three expectations for the functioning of the hemicycle. The first involves “further enhancing the leadership role of the Legislative Assembly in political terms”, in what he explained as a role in promoting nationalism and maintaining harmony in the long term. Secondly, he also asked deputies to “further enhance the role of the Legislative Assembly in drafting legislation and monitoring”, which he explained involved deputies “working together with the executive body” to create and review legislation considered key for the Executive, such as the diversification of the economy. Finally, the AL was asked to be a “fundamental interlocutor” in collecting opinions from “public opinion”, while also indicating that it expected deputies to guide “society to form an environment for positive, objective and rational discussion” and “promote the broadest possible social consensus to support the Macao SAR Government”.

item.title: São Januário | First artificial heart implanted in Macau
item.description: The first surgery to implant an artificial heart was recently carried out at the Conde de São Januário Hospital Center (CHCSJ) of Health Services (SS), in collaboration with the cardiothoracic surgery team of the First Affiliated Hospital of Jinan University. The procedure was carried out on a 68-year-old woman who suffered from terminal heart failure, and, according to a statement from the SS, “the condition presented was complex and the surgical intervention challenging”. It was “the first surgical procedure to implant a completely magnetically levitated artificial heart, developed autonomously in Mainland China”. Carrying out this surgery in the territory represents, for the authorities, “significant progress in cardiac surgery in Macau”. For the SS, “the successful completion of the first artificial heart implant surgery in Macau represents a significant advance in the treatment of terminal heart failure in the region”, in addition to this technological advance “fills a significant gap in medical care, offering a viable and safe alternative for patients who are not eligible for heart transplantation or who cannot wait for a surgical intervention”.

item.title: UPM | Creative Macau hosts exhibition with student works
item.description: The Creative Macau gallery hosts, until November 8th, the exhibition “Prototype – Exhibition of Works by Students of the Degree in Media Arts”, from the Macau Polytechnic University. There are 30 works by more than 20 students who attend this course and who show all their creativity here Creative Macau hosts a new exhibition composed of works of art by students from the Macau Polytechnic University. This is “Prototype” – Exhibition of Works by Students of the Degree Course in Media Arts at the Macau Polytechnic University (UPM) 2025″, and can be seen until November 8th, with free entry. The exhibition presents more than 30 works of art by around 20 students who attend the degree program at UPM, with the public being able to see “a curated selection of notable works by students from the first to the third year” of the aforementioned course, explains a note from Creative Macau. You will be able to see a “diversity of work, ranging from interactive digital experiences to physical creations, reflecting the program's balanced emphasis on both theoretical foundations and practical application”. Thus, “through practical work in various courses, students acquired proficiency in a wide range of design tools and production techniques, transforming abstract ideas into fully realized works.” “Important milestone” Creative Macau further describes that this exhibition, and the opportunity that students have to show the results of their work, “constitutes an important milestone in their academic journey”. “By sharing these creations with the public, we hope to stimulate a broader dialogue and exchange about media arts, emerging technologies and the cultural future they continue to shape”, it is further stated. Creative Macau – Creative Industries Center was founded in 2003 and has been managed by the Macau Institute of European Studies. Over the years, Creative Macau has supported projects and artistic works in 12 areas of the creative industries, including advertising, architecture, design, fashion or crafts. “Its objective is to help these industries reach their full economic potential, adding value and promoting recognition in society”, it is further described. In the case of the degree in Media Arts at UPM, the objective is to “train high-quality media arts professionals through a curriculum that emphasizes multidisciplinary learning in the areas of arts, design and technology”. The aim here is that “students develop communication skills, international vision, intercultural understanding and innovative thinking, while at the same time acquiring knowledge and skills in media arts in the areas of interaction in games, technological art and video storytelling”.

item.title: Japan's Liberal Party close to securing new coalition deal
item.description: The Liberal Democratic Party (PLD), in power in Japan, is close to forming a government coalition, which would leave leader Sanae Takaichi just two deputies away from securing election as prime minister. The main Japanese media reported yesterday that the agreement with the Innovation Party of Japan (Ishin) could be closed as early as Monday, the day before parliament meets to choose Shigeru Ishiba's successor. The outgoing prime minister resigned in September from the leadership of the Government and the PLD, which, in primaries held at the beginning of October, chose the conservative and nationalist Takaichi as the candidate to be the first woman to lead Japan. According to the Japanese news agency Kyodo, the PLD and Ishin have agreed to form a coalition without the opposition party guaranteeing seats in the new Government. In return, the PLD would commit to complying with a series of proposals, including reducing the number of deputies, eliminating the tax on food consumption and eliminating political donations from companies and organizations. Today, a final meeting with the PLD is expected. Fragile leadership The newspaper reported that the opposition party is reluctant to occupy positions in Takaichi's possible government and prefers to first ensure that the new PLD leader complies with the terms of the agreement. If elected, the conservative would lead one of the weakest governments in Japan's political history, with a clear minority in both chambers of parliament, which would force her to cooperate with the opposition to pass any law. Ishin's support is essential for Takaichi, especially after the Buddhist party Komeito, with which the PLD was allied for 26 years, abandoned the ruling coalition. The centrist Komeito withdrew from the alliance due to published news about alleged secret PLD funds, having also criticized Sanae Takaichi due to supposed changes in the leader's stance regarding visits to Yasukuni. Diplomatic fears Takaichi, known for her hard-line stance towards China, has visited the Shinto shrine numerous times in the past, especially when she was minister, considered a symbol of the country's militaristic past. But, on Friday, on the first day of the Yasukuni Autumn Festival, 64 years old, he was absent and sent only one offering, because, according to Japanese media, he feared that a visit could upset neighboring countries. Previous visits by senior Japanese officials to the shrine have angered Beijing and Seoul. China and the Korean peninsula were the scene of atrocities committed by the Japanese military in the first half of the 20th century. No sitting Japanese prime minister has visited the shrine in Tokyo since 2013, when Shinzo Abe's visit sparked fury among neighboring countries and rebukes from the United States. The shrine pays tribute to the approximately 2.5 million Japanese soldiers killed in combat, but also to Japanese officers and politicians convicted of war crimes by an international tribunal after World War II. The LDP has governed Japan almost permanently since 1955, despite frequent leadership changes.

item.title: UM joins the UNESCO Chair dedicated to Portuguese heritage
item.description: The University of Macau (UM) announced its membership of the UNESCO Chair in Intercultural Dialogue on Heritage of Portuguese Influence, a project launched by the University of Coimbra (UC). Num comunicado divulgado na sexta-feira à noite, a UM defendeu que a entrada no projecto “imprime uma nova dinâmica no desenvolvimento da investigação sobre património cultural” em Macau. The collaboration with UC will promote “international academic exchange in Macau”, as well as strengthen “ties” with higher education institutions in Portuguese-speaking countries, UM added. The institution's formal accession to the UNESCO Chair took place in a ceremony organized by the two institutions in Macau, on Wednesday, with the presence of Rui Martins, vice-rector of UM, and João Nuno Calvão da Silva, vice-rector of UC. Rui Martins argued that UM's entry “will further enrich the academic resources and cultural perspective” of the already “wide network of partners” established by the UNESCO Chair. The UC created the project in 2018, to explore “the multicultural results resulting from the influence of Portuguese-speaking culture”, such as architecture, arts, language, literature, landscape and urbanism, said the statement. At the time, the UNESCO Chair already involved fifty teachers and researchers in a partnership with several European, Brazilian and African institutions. Comprehensive effort The list included the University of Bologna Studies (Italy), the Universidade Federal Fluminense (Brazil), the universities Eduardo Mondlane and Lúrio (Mozambique), the University Paris Nanterre (France) and MEIA – Mindelo Escola Internacional de Arte (Cape Verde). Rui Martins, a Portuguese academic who has long lived in Macau, highlighted that the UNESCO Chair is an international project “that integrates research, training and cooperation for development”. In the case of UM, the Department of Integrated Resorts and Tourism Management of the Faculty of Business Management will “actively demonstrate its professional competence” in research into cultural heritage, guaranteed Martins. The UNESCO Chair is coordinated by researcher Walter Rossa, who on Wednesday spoke about “the political significance” of research on cultural heritage within the organization's policies.

item.title: Today Macau
item.description: A bad writer “will never write a good novel using artificial intelligence”, said writer José Eduardo Agualusa this Saturday at FOLIO – Óbidos International Literary Festival, arguing that this instrument does not pose a danger to authors and may even have some potential. “I believe that a bad writer will never write a good novel using artificial intelligence”, but “perhaps a good writer will be able to write a better novel once he knows how to use this instrument”, he added. At a panel of authors in which he assured that artificial intelligence does not scare him, the Angolan writer considered that this instrument “is still used in a trivial way” by many people, but that when “if you know how to use it well, you will probably discover greater potential”. Even so, he considers that there is no danger of “writers being replaced”, because artificial intelligence “mimics, reproduces the writer’s style”, but “the imitation of the style is normally ridiculous”. In other chapters “that instrument is very useful”, he said, giving as an example the Angolan chronicle in the newspapers, which “improved a lot, because it corrects very well”. “In the case of Angola it is very clear, suddenly the chroniclers started to write better, any emergency we ask for and the weekly column comes out”. However, in the long narrative, in the novel, “the AI ​​still has a big challenge” and, even if one day it manages to write “a mediocre novel” it will have to have “someone behind it, with creativity”. Conversations on FOLIO José Eduardo Agualusa spoke at the 12th panel of FOLIO, in a conversation with Brazilian writer Giovana Madalosso, where both argued that literature is not in danger, despite movements of censorship and cancellation of writers in countries like Brazil. Because “more and more people are reading. More and more people are reading better”, said Agualusa. The FOLIO ended yesterday. This year marked the tenth year of existence with more than 460 initiatives, including more than a hundred conversations between authors and the public, 15 author tables, gatherings, seminars, book launches, concerts and prize giving.

item.title: Paulo Maia and Carmo
item.description: Sun Yang, who lived in the time of Spring and Autumn (771-476 BC) because he was considered an exemplary judge in choosing a good horse, earned the honorific title of Bole from a king, «the happy eldest» and his praised ability to choose gave rise to the popular saying that says that «good horses capable of running a thousand li in a day (qianlima) are many, a Bole is rare». This would soon be adopted as a metaphor for all areas where it was necessary or vital to know how to choose talent, especially hidden talent such as in the selection of government employees. But this skill, specifically referring to horses, was especially valued in the time of the dynasty founded by the Mongol knights of the Yuan. The most notable painters of that time, such as Zhao Mengfu, portrayed several of the dynasty's most famous horses. And a court painter around the year 1342 showed, with indifference, a horse offered to the emperor, as was customary in the tax system with foreign countries, but which would remain as unexpected visual proof of the stay in the territory of a mission headed by the Florentine Franciscan Giovanni de Marignolli (c. 1290- 1358) who had arrived in Khanbaliq (present-day Beijing) as legate of the Pope in 1339-40, following the unprecedented reception of Giovanni da Montecorvino OFM (1247-1328) at the Yuan court, which even allowed him to build churches in the streets of the capital. This horizontal scroll made only in ink, a copy of which was probably made in the Ming dynasty and is in the Palace Museum in Beijing, is attributed to the court painter Zhou Lang, who created in another painting an unforgettable portrait of a poet whose memory is largely due to the testimony of a contemporary capable of recognizing her unique talent. Zhou Lang made the portrait of Du Qiuniang, «the Autumn Maiden» (791-835), with an ancient flute in his hands in a figurative style respecting the «spirit of the ancients» as Zhao Mengfu wanted, and on the model of the ladies of the Tang dynasty. From the portrait in this horizontal scroll (ink and color on silk, 32.3 x 285 cm in the Palace Museum in Beijing) was an exhortation to a prince, which would last and can be translated as: «I ask you, Lord: do not be dazzled / by the lives of those who carry gold / in the seams of their dresses/ My advice, Lord, / is that your green years / be well lived. / Pick the flowers when they bloom, / not when they are already falling, / Don’t wait until there are no longer / flowers on the broken branches.” It is known about the author that she was educated in the arts of dance and music and impressed a general who was defeated by an emperor and took her to his court and, following political conflicts, returned to her native Nanking. And it was there that, aged and impoverished, the poet Du Mu (803-52) found her, who wrote a poem about her and her brief biography.

item.title: Death | António Coelho dies aged 77, but leaves a legacy in Portuguese gastronomy
item.description: The founder of Restaurante António died on Sunday in Macau, due to heart problems. Behind him, he leaves a mark and an innovative concept for promoting Portuguese food in Asia A father, a friend and one of the great ambassadors of Portuguese gastronomy in Asia. Chef António Coelho died on Sunday, aged 77, due to heart problems, but leaves behind a professional career spanning almost 40 years and an influence that can be felt in several restaurants and Portuguese food chefs in Macau. Born in Portugal in 1948, António Coelho's first contact with Macau took place in 1970, when he had to complete his four-year mandatory military service. After two years, the land remained in his memory, but the future chef chose to return to Europe. In Portugal, he started working at Social Security, later moving to a clinical analysis laboratory. It was in this area that he developed his taste for gastronomy, not through work, but through various lunches and dinners in different restaurants. Increasingly interested in cooking, António decided to take a job, in 1984, in a restaurant, where he admitted to having learned to cook, according to an interview with the South China Morning Post newspaper, in 2018. The first years of António Coelho's new career were spent in Portugal, where he performed different roles as manager-administrator of the Botequim do Rei restaurant or director of the catering department at the Grande Hotel da Curia. In 1996, he had his first international experience, as director of the restaurant department at the Hotel Trópico, in Cape Verde. The experience lasts one year. Creating a legacy Returning to Macau in 1997, António worked for 10 years in different spaces, such as the restaurants Frol de la Mar, Lusitano, Lisbon, and also had a brief stay in Hong Kong, in 2002, at Restaurante Inn. However, the decisive step towards his affirmation as one of the most influential chefs of Portuguese gastronomy in Asia came in 2007, with the opening of Restaurante António. And the success that followed was not the result of chance, as said by Edgar Rodrigues, a chef who came to Macau to work on the launch of the project: “The success was based on the recipes, the quality of the food, but also the very professionalism”, says Edgar Rodrigues, to HM. "He was very attentive to his customers. If there was an order for clams à bolhão pato, he would have different recipes adapted to the nationality. For example, Koreans don't like coriander, the recipe for them didn't have coriander. Chinese customers like little salt, they were served with little salt, and locals like the more traditional recipe. In a single dish there were several ways of cooking, just to satisfy different customers", he recalls. Cristiano Tavares, currently chef at the Macalhau restaurant, also came to Macau to work at the António Restaurant. He believes that the chef found a position for Portuguese food that still influences other restaurants today. “I think his success was due to his way of being, he was a politically correct person, he had a way of working that pleased both Chinese, Korean and Japanese tourists”, explained Cristiano Tavares, to HM. "We were a street restaurant with four or five cooks. He managed to do what many large restaurants still cannot do today. Nowadays there are many restaurants with Portuguese food that open in Macau, but follow the example of what he did", he considered. Quality and spectacle In addition to the food, Restaurante António customers were seduced by the “show”. This is the vision of Marcelino Marques, António's friend and musician who for several years livened up the space's nights, with traditional Portuguese music. "The quality of the food made the space popular. He took great care in choosing the food and drinks served. He went to Portugal to choose wines from various regions, such as Douro or Alentejo, all of high quality, which were bottled under the António brand. People knew they weren't going to pay little, not that it was a space with luxury prices, it wasn't, but the quantity served wasn't small", recalled Marcelino Marques. However, the musician believes that the success was also due to a concept in which the meal was also a spectacle: "People liked listening to Portuguese music, but also being with António. He was an affable, big person and appeared in that white jacket with the flags of Portugal, China and Macau and people liked his presence and asked him to take photographs", he says. "He also opened a bottle of champagne with a sword. He did a whole ceremony and people really liked it. It was a spectacle and a party to see the cork flying out of the bottle. It worked well", he recalled. Marcelino Marques recalls that the food and the show made the restaurant very famous, especially among Japanese, Korean and Hong Kong tourists. The musician reveals that Japanese tourists booked days in advance. And this factor also contributed to the fact that António offered a glass of port wine at the end of the meal, which also led to the recognition of the Port Wine Confraternity. The success of Restaurante António led the chef to sell the space to an investment fund, becoming an ambassador for the space. The break with the fund happened in 2020, when he was fired without just cause. The case ended up in court, with António winning the case. In recent years, António took on the position of executive chef at Angela’s Café and Lounge, at the Hotel Lisboeta. A father, a friend Due to his work in Macau, António was distinguished, in 2013, by the Macao SAR Government with the MSAR Tourist Merit Medal. Also in 2015, he received the merit medal for Portuguese communities from the Portuguese Government. However, for those who worked with him the most important thing was the relationship that went beyond the strictly professional field. "He had a big impact on Macau and for me he was like a second father. When I came to Macau I didn't have an easy life and he always held my hand", confessed Rodrigues. "He was always a person who was there for me. And I always saw him as a man of iron. In everything he did, there was a great will", he pointed out. This is a feeling shared by Cristiano Tavares. "António is my father in Macau. He worked until the last day, always with seriousness, honesty and integrity. He is an example for all the chefs in this area", he said. For Marcelino Marques, António's death is the loss of a friend. "António was the person who welcomed me to Macau and was capable of doing the same to everyone. He was strict and demanding, but he was an excellent person", he described. "Everyone knew him. He was an affable person and received people like no one else", he added.

item.title: Chemistry | Nobel Prize for the development of metal-organic structures
item.description: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded to Susumu Kitagawa, from Kyoto University, Richard Robson, from the University of Melbourne, and Omar M. Yaghi, from the University of California, “for the development of metal-organic structures”, the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences announced yesterday. Susumu Kitagawa, Richard Robson and Omar Yaghi have developed a new form of molecular architecture – metal-organic frameworks – that can be used to collect water from desert air, capture carbon dioxide, store toxic gases or catalyze chemical reactions. The three laureates created molecular constructs with large spaces through which gases and other chemicals could flow. The president of the Nobel Committee for Chemistry, Heiner Linque, highlighted precisely the fact that these “metal-organic structures have enormous potential, bringing previously unforeseen opportunities for personalized materials with new functions”. The research that led to the discovery of this new form of molecular architecture began nearly four decades ago, in 1989, when Richard Robson tested the use of the inherent properties of atoms by combining positively charged copper ions with a four-armed molecule. When combined, they bonded "to form a spacious, well-ordered crystal. It was like a diamond filled with countless cavities," the academy explains. Robson immediately realized the potential of his molecular construction, but it was still unstable and crumbled easily. It was chemists Susumu Kitagawa and Omar Yaghi who managed to provide a solid foundation for this construction method. Notable applications Following the discoveries of the three laureates, chemists built tens of thousands of different MOFs. Some of them could contribute to solving some of humanity's biggest challenges, with applications including breaking down traces of pharmaceuticals in the environment, capturing carbon dioxide or collecting water from desert air. The discovery also allows the separation of perfluoroalkylated and polyfluoroalkylated substances (PFAS) from water. PFAS are a group of synthetic chemical compounds known as “forever chemicals” due to their extreme persistence in the environment and in the human body. PFAS are used in a wide range of industrial and household products, such as stain- and water-resistant textiles, food packaging, non-stick cookware and firefighting foams. Its accumulation in the environment and potential health risks, including liver damage and other problems, have led to concerns and a search for safer alternatives.

item.title: Study | Trump was the main disseminator of disinformation in the USA in 2024
item.description: North American President Donald Trump was the main disseminator of disinformation in the United States of America (USA) in 2024, concluded a study by the International Center for Journalists (ICFJ). “US President Donald Trump was the dominant source and distributor of disinformation” in 2024, say the authors of the study “Disarming Disinformation: United States”. The study highlights that Trump has drawn on the functions of domestic political forces, rather than foreign state actors, as the main source of disinformation narratives in US political discourse. Furthermore, the existence of WhatsApp groups and other closed digital spaces often act as “information cocoons” that encourage rumors and other forms of misinformation. In this way, "the viral spread of misinformation and the strategic attack on journalists have emerged as interconnected threats to democracy. In an era of increasing authoritarianism and democratic backsliding, falsehoods are often used as a weapon by state actors to influence public opinion, undermine journalism and intimidate journalists." The study authors state that these factors are increasingly the North American reality, with Donald Trump “promulgating manifestly false narratives” in recent years. “The American media faces a profound information crisis, at a time of repression of freedom of expression”, the study reads. In this sense, trust in the mainstream press continues to decline in a climate of increasing attacks on the media by the Trump Government. The study published by the International Center for Journalists (ICFJ) was based on the analysis of 10,000 news and media publications during 2024, as well as a survey of 1,020 Americans.

item.title: Cuts leave 13.7 million people at risk of extreme hunger
item.description: Cuts in humanitarian aid funding could expose up to 13.7 million people to extreme hunger around the world, the World Food Program (WFP) warned yesterday. “The humanitarian aid system is under severe pressure as partners withdraw from frontline areas, creating a void,” the Rome-based agency said in a new report titled “A lifebuoy in danger.” The UN agency said that six of its operations – in Afghanistan, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Haiti, Somalia, South Sudan and Sudan – are “facing major disruptions, which will only worsen”. WFP warned that its financing “has never been so challenging”, anticipating “a 40 percent drop” in 2025, “which will translate into a projected budget of US$6.4 billion, compared to US$10 billion in 2024”. The report does not name any countries, but points to a study published in the medical journal The Lancet, which found that 14 million additional deaths worldwide from disease, nutritional deficiencies and maternal and perinatal conditions could occur by 2030 as a result of cuts in US humanitarian aid alone. Returns and records Since US President Donald Trump's return to the White House, Washington has announced massive cuts in its foreign aid, dealing a huge blow to humanitarian operations around the world. "Program coverage has been significantly reduced and rations cut. Vital assistance to families in food disaster situations [Phase 5 of the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification/IPC] is threatened, while preparedness for future impacts has significantly decreased," warns WFP. Globally, “WFP estimates that its funding gaps could push 10.5 to 13.7 million people currently in acute food insecurity (IPC Phase 3) into a humanitarian emergency (IPC Phase 4),” the organization added. The UN agency said global hunger has now reached record levels, with 319 million people facing acute food insecurity — including 44 million at emergency levels.

item.title: Scientists ‘reduce’ the age of the Egyptian temple of Karnak, in Egypt
item.description: Researchers have carried out the most comprehensive geoarchaeological study of the Karnak temple, near Luxor, and revealed suggestive links to ancient Egyptian mythology and new data about the interaction between the complex's riverine landscape and the people who occupied the site during its almost 3,000 years of use. The results of the investigation were published on Monday in Antiquity magazine, reported the Efe news agency. Researchers from the University of Southampton, in the United Kingdom, and Uppsala University, in Sweden, participated in the study. Up to 61 sediment samples from the interior and surroundings of the temple and thousands of ceramic fragments found in the Karnak complex, located 500 meters east of the current Nile River, near Luxor, in the ancient Egyptian religious capital of Thebes, were analyzed. The researchers mapped how the landscape around the site changed throughout its history and found that, before 2520 BC, the site could not have been suitable for permanent occupation due to periodic flooding caused by the Nile's strong currents. Therefore, they placed the earliest occupation at Karnak during the Old Kingdom (between 2591 and 2152 BC). Pottery fragments found at the site corroborate this discovery, with the oldest dating between 2305 and 1980 BC. Therefore, the conclusions of this international team of researchers provide new evidence about the age of Karnak, which has been hotly debated in archaeological circles for decades. The origin of everything The ground on which the temple was founded was formed when river channels advanced west and east, creating an island of high ground in what is now the east-southeast region of the site. This emerging island laid the foundation for the occupation and initial construction of Karnak. Over the following centuries and millennia, the river channels on both sides of the site diverged further, creating more space for the development of the temple complex, as researchers have now confirmed. This new understanding of the temple's landscape bears striking similarities to an ancient Egyptian creation myth, leading the team to believe that the decision to locate the temple there may have been related to the religious views of its inhabitants. Ancient Egyptian texts from the Old Kingdom indicate that the 'Creator God' manifested himself as high ground emerging from the lake, and researchers have found that the island where Karnak was founded is the only known area of ​​high ground surrounded by water in the region. Thus, archaeologists have suggested that the Theban elites chose the location of Karnak to be the abode of a new form of 'Creator God', alluding to Amun-Ra, the supreme god of ancient Egypt, since the location fit perfectly into the mythological setting of the highlands that emerged from the surrounding waters as the origin of the formation of the Universe.

item.title: Physics | Nobel Prize for Macroscopic Quantum Mechanical Tunneling
item.description: The Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded to John Clarke, Michel H. Devoret and John M. Martinis “for the discovery of macroscopic quantum mechanical tunneling and the quantization of energy in an electrical circuit”, announced yesterday the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences. "An important question in physics is the maximum size of a system capable of demonstrating the effects of quantum mechanics. This year's Nobel Prize laureates carried out experiments with an electrical circuit in which they demonstrated both quantum tunneling and quantized energy levels in a system large enough to be held in the hand", explains the Swedish Academy of Sciences in a statement published on its website. The British John Clarke carried out his research at the University of California, Berkeley, USA; the American John Martinis at the University of California, Santa Barbara; and the Frenchman Michel Devoret at Yale University and also in California, Santa Barbara. According to academia, quantum mechanics allows a particle to directly cross a barrier, through a process called tunneling. When a large number of particles are involved, quantum effects usually become negligible. The experiments of the now distinguished scientists demonstrated that quantum properties can be made concrete on a macroscopic scale. "It is wonderful to be able to celebrate the way in which quantum mechanics, more than a century old, continues to offer new surprises. It is also extremely useful, as it is the basis of all digital technology", said the president of the Nobel Committee for Physics, Olle Eriksson, quoted in the statement. The Swedish academy says that transistors in computer microchips are an example of consolidated quantum technology. The scientists today awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics share a prize of 11 million Swedish kronor (almost one million euros).

item.title: Linguistics | Published study based on a trip to Macau in the 19th century
item.description:
Academic Anabela Leal de Barros has just published a linguistic study that focuses on the trip of Father Miranda e Oliveira, linked to the Congregation of the Mission, to Macau in 1825. With touches of history, details are revealed about the Portuguese of the time and of Macau. The book will be presented at the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center next Wednesday
“Journey from Lisbon to Macau – 1825” is the title of the most recent work published by Grão-Falar, written by University of Minho academic Anabela Leal de Barros. The book makes a critical and interpretative analysis of the Portuguese of the time left in the manuscript of parish priest José Joaquim de Miranda e Oliveira, priest of the Congregation of the Mission. This documentation is kept by the Braga District Archive. However, the work does not just explore the Portuguese of the time, revealing other historical details of Macau, Asia and a sea voyage. As Anabela Leal de Barros told HM, the work is “as faithful as possible to the spelling of the manuscript”, until now practically unknown. In this travel diary, Father Miranda e Oliveira “reveals enormous curiosity about all the news and shares with us their names in the languages ​​of the world in which they were baptized, starting with ours”. This is how he explains situations such as “seasickness, a reality that was still relatively unknown and highly invasive on boats” in those times. The priest named or defined “the mangalhões, the porpoises, the caravels, the black-eyed peas, the flies, the albacores — all sorts of birds and fish that were admired, fished or tasted throughout the trip”, or even the “meteorological phenomena with local names – cacimba, samatra, typhoon”. There are also details about “cultural habits such as the masca, buio in Indonesian; the Philippine seges, the berloches, and the ruling class of the camisolas, as well as the sômas, Chinese vessels”. The vessel left Lisbon in April 1825 and spent time in the Philippines, arriving in Macau on October 23rd. The arrival “to the island of Caó” and the following day “to Colégio de S. José” is described, to “a city with ‘a magnificent port of commerce’, located ‘on a very pleasant peninsula’, with ‘good waters’ and ‘famous European-style buildings'”. Linguistic varieties In the work published by Grão-Falar there are, for example, “rich stories such as that of Orvalhadas de S. João, Caldeirão de Frei Junípero or the habit of seafarers shouting ‘Refresca S. Lourenço!’ so that the wind blows, this being the meaning here of ‘refresh’”. There are also “allusions to the linguistic variety itself”, as “at various times there is reference to communication with foreigners carried out in Latin, in Indonesian-Dutch and Filipino-Spanish territory; the private teaching of English in the Philippines by members of the Congregation of the Mission; the little knowledge and use of Spanish, even in Manila, and the variation of Tagalog itself, a language in which the priest is concerned about recording the Hail Mary.” Before arriving at this travel report, Anabela Leal de Barros was already in the intricacies of investigating this type of manuscripts, coming across the story of another priest, “the greatest Portuguese sinologist, Joaquim Afonso Gonçalves, who had traveled from the same house as Rilhafoles of the Congregation of the Mission to Macau in 1812”. According to the author, this parish priest “dedicated the last twenty-nine years of his life to the mission of evangelization in China, and in particular to the research and teaching of Chinese at the Colégio de S. José in Macau”. In his entire life, “this Trás-os-Montes native wrote more than five thousand pages of grammars and dictionaries in Portuguese, Latin and Chinese, expressly dedicated to his students at the College, seven printed in his typography and at least two manuscripts”. Then, in 2017, António Lázaro, from the History Department of the University of Minho, and director of the Confúcio Institute, made available to Anabela Leal de Barros “a list of references to manuscripts from the Braga District Archive about Macau and China”. A “journey” began, which culminated in the publication of this study. “This book is the first result of a project of mine to edit and study unpublished travel literature manuscripts whose main objective is exactly this: to contribute to the appreciation and consolidation of the micro-history of the Discoveries and the memory of history, between the 15th and 19th centuries”. Accompanied on the trip José Joaquim de Miranda e Oliveira took around seven months to arrive in Macau, leaving Lisbon on April 1, 1825, and arriving in Oriente on October 24 of the same year. He left on the ship Vasco da Gama with three other priests from the congregation: João da França de Castro e Moura, Jerónimo José da Mata and José́ Ferreira da Silva. According to Anabela Leal de Barros, “the manuscript does not appear to have been cleaned by the author himself, given the type of spelling variations and typos and amendments it presents”, having probably been “translated, to safeguard copies, by a Macanese member of the College, since Macau Portuguese, in the 19th century, had characteristics compatible with certain traits, strange in a priest arrived from Portugal, even how young.” This travel diary “ends on the very day of arrival in Macau, with a very brief presentation of the city and the school, making clear the Catholic perspective of the time in relation to the Chinese cult of ancestors and without failing to draw attention to the mere five thousand Christians among the 40 to 50 thousand inhabitants of the city”. Political hostilities José Joaquim de Miranda e Oliveira describes how the bishop of Macau did not receive the delegation, which is “enough to lead us to the hostile context in which the Lazarists, defenders of liberalism, found themselves, which had led Joaquim Afonso Gonçalves, a few years earlier, to take refuge in the Philippines, with the school missing two of its teachers”. Furthermore, “along the journey the priest does not fail to narrate all the moments in which he carries out his daily mission, with the administration of the sacraments, the prayer of responsos and the celebration of masses, but above all he notes the notable lack of priests who reveal the Christianized peoples, particularly in Batavia, now Jakarta, where the community of Portuguese origin, of more than a thousand people, had only an old priest.” These reports also reveal the concern to “remember the first French martyrs of the Congregation in the attempt to evangelize Madagascar and to report the presence of friars and priests from the different congregations, from Cape Verde to the Philippines, where they are recognized as more important for the solidity of Spanish rule than its army”. According to Anabela Leal de Barros, the report also alluded, in Java, “to the Lutherans and Mohammedans, as well as to the religions of China and, in Manila, to the persecution of Christians (referring to the ‘dinner’, that is, lunch with a Chinese Christian, ‘and as such persecuted’)”. Miranda and Oliveira had “a very diplomatic and convivial conduct, ensuring the establishment and maintenance of cordial relations between the various orders and also with the governors and foreign powers present, from the Dutch to the Spanish, who visited everywhere”. An ongoing project In those years, it was a dangerous adventure to travel by boat, facing “anthropogenic peoples, piracy, diseases on ships and epidemics”, a “perfectly cinematic vision” already described in Os Lusíadas, by Luís de Camões. Those who embarked on these trips also found themselves alone, “individually and on a small ship little more than a walnut shell, facing an endless sea, for months, at times when it was common for several passengers not to reach their destination, or for not even one ship from a full squadron to return”. In Miranda and Oliveira's report, “there is no great news” compared to previous reports, but “we are aware of the main difficulties of sea voyages to Asia in the 19th century: the rocks that existed even before the Torre de Belém, which caused many shipwrecks; and seasickness, which even deserves a definition for the many readers who had never set foot on a boat, and to which the captain's face advising the sick ladies going up to the awning and working, as it was the best medicine”. There is also “the episode of the man falling overboard from the plow that accompanied them on part of the trip, which they were unable to save — a death to which everyone was so exposed, as the narrator refers”. Another potential misfortune in trips of this type also stands out, “the encounter with ships that, not immediately raising any flag, or raising it without giving true confidence, immediately led to the decision to light the hills and open fire, which well reflects the dimension of piracy and the fears it imposed”. Essentially, “the main character of sea voyages was the wind”, which led the still “young priest” to “evoke the Camonian verses of the storm twice”. After arriving in Macau, Miranda e Oliveira left for his post in Nanking, “on a journey comparatively longer than the first, received by the Christians with difficulty and secretly”. “In the face of persecution” he ended up succumbing “to the dangers and illnesses of the mainland, at the age of 31, far from all his confreres, on November 1, 1828, just two years after having described the difficult farewell to his spiritual family, in Lisbon”. “His traveling companions had more longevity, one of whom would become Bishop of Macau and the other of Beijing and Porto”, highlights Anabela Leal de Barros.

item.title: Bridges | Advisor suggests tolls and generates chorus of criticism
item.description:
On October 10th, Leong Chi Hang, member of the Consultative Council of Community Services of the Islands, suggested the introduction of toll payments on the four bridges that cross between the Macau peninsula and Taipa. The opinion sparked controversy on social media and even led a listener to call in to the morning show on Radio Macau's Chinese channel.
Councilor Leong Chi Hang, member of the Consultative Council for Community Services of the Islands, defended at a meeting of this body, on October 10th, that tolls should be paid on the four bridges that cross between the Macau peninsula and the islands. This suggestion was made during the period of interventions before the agenda of the aforementioned organization, with Leong Chi Hang, who is also vice-president of the Taipa Community Development Promotion Association, arguing that it is necessary for the Government to improve and reform the bridge management system due to frequent traffic jams in these road infrastructures. "I suggest that an electronic collection system be created with tolls on these four bridges, and the collection would be made according to different periods, vehicles. An additional fee could be added in times of greater circulation", he said. According to Leong Chi Hang, the objective of charging tolls would be to balance the flow of vehicles on the four bridges by adjusting the toll charges, as for some people the increased costs of crossing the bridge by car may make them opt more for public transport. In this way, priority will be given to public transport and more environmentally friendly travel. Fired fuse This opinion was publicized on social media during the Advisory Council meeting, especially in Facebook groups, which generated a wave of critical opinions. And the wave of protest did not stop on social media: on Friday a resident, surnamed Ma, called the morning program Forum Macau on the Chinese channel Radio Macau, criticizing this measure, arguing that, to alleviate the traffic situation on bridges, procedures for dealing with road accidents should be simplified. "I don't think [charging tolls] is a viable suggestion, as bridges are always filled with traffic and an additional charge is still being advocated. Traffic jams often occur on bridges not due to an excess of cars, but rather due to the occurrence of road accidents. Why can't we simplify procedures similar to what happens in Mainland China?", he asked. This listener argued that “if [a road accident] does not involve criminal proceedings, and it is enough to take photographs of the accident, the vehicles involved in the accident can be removed from the scene” more quickly. Ma also complained about the fact that Macau continues to maintain an outdated system for dealing with road accidents, even though the territory has recently adopted digital solutions, such as the installation of video surveillance cameras, which end up not being well used to deal with this type of cases.

item.title: Takeaway | Request for worker protection
item.description: Deputy Leong Hong Sai questions the Government about whether it has plans to legislate the status of workers on online food delivery platforms. The matter was raised by the deputy linked to the Residents, through a written interpellation published on Friday. In the document, Leong points out as a problem the fact that distributors are considered “independent workers”, but they are nevertheless subject to complying with the employer's orders, as in a traditional employment relationship. “Currently, several online food and order delivery platforms in Macau define their workers as ‘independent workers’ or ‘partners’, thus excluding them from legal labor protections,” he accused. “It is understood that some platforms allocate orders through algorithms and implement incentive schemes, preventing platform workers from enjoying the autonomy typical of traditional independent work,” he added. The deputy therefore asks the Executive to create a legal statute to ensure the labor protection of distributors. “Will authorities review existing regulations governing employment relationships to comprehensively regulate online food and parcel delivery platforms?” he asks. “Furthermore, will they make appropriate adjustments in response to changes in the labor market to promptly clarify the legal status, responsibilities and rights of both companies and platform workers?”, he asks.

item.title: Ponte-Cais no. 11 | Government moves forward with land recovery
item.description: The Government ordered the occupants of the land at Ponte-Cais no. 11 to vacate the space, considering that the “temporary occupation license” expired around 44 years ago. The information is contained in a notice from the Directorate of Land and Urban Construction Services (DSSCU), dated October 3rd. According to the document, the license to occupy the Ponte-Cais no. 11 land was issued on April 14, 1980 and had a deadline of December 31, 1980. However, after the deadline, there was never any request to renew the license. “According to the letter sent by the Directorate of Maritime Affairs and Water Services on August 18, 2025, there is no document that reveals the registration of a request for renewal of the said license, which is why it automatically expired due to the expiration of the term”, can be read in the notice. The occupants, one of whom was identified as Chan Meng, have now been given a period of 45 days, from the publication of the notice, to vacate the land. The document also clarifies that if the eviction does not occur voluntarily within 45 days, the authorities have the power to proceed coercively. The land is located on Rua das Lorchas with Ponte-Cais no. 11 in good condition. The lot has an area of ​​199 square meters.

item.title: LAG 2026 | More than 3,500 opinions collected
item.description: Sam Hou Fai, Chief Executive of the Macao SAR, told journalists that 3,548 opinions and suggestions were collected regarding the Governing Action Lines (LAG) for next year. Quoted in an official note, regarding the opening, this weekend, of the Government headquarters to the population, Sam Hou Fai explained that the work of collecting opinions was carried out for a month and ended on Friday. The official also said that in terms of the number of opinions and suggestions, there was “an increase compared to previous years”. The opening of the Government Headquarters to the public took place on Saturday and Sunday and, according to the same official note, “some residents stated that it was worth visiting the Government Headquarters, noting that this was not their first visit and that, this time, they had the pleasure of meeting the Chief Executive, taking photographs and chatting friendly, feeling his solidarity”. There were also tourists visiting the Executive headquarters, who mentioned “the charm and specific architectural characteristics of the Government Headquarters Protocol Palace”. Opinions were also recorded regarding the “themed flower exhibition in the garden”, which was considered “beautiful, and the shows on site were appealing”.

item.title: AL | André Cheong promises presidency to meet expectations
item.description: At the beginning of the new legislature, deputies received “three expectations” from the Chief Executive, one of which involves “working together” with the Government, but also exercising law enforcement functions. When performing the duties of president of the Legislative Assembly, André Cheong promises to keep in mind the Chief Executive's expectations for the work of the legislative body. The statements were made by the new president of the hemicycle, in an interview with TDM's Chinese-language channels. "As president of the Legislative Assembly I feel that the weight of responsibility is greater. I will strictly comply with the provisions of the law and regulations to carry out my duties as president", stated the new president of the AL, quoted by Canal Macau. “At the same time, I will take into account the three expectations established by the Chief Executive for the new composition of the Legislative Assembly, leading the team well in legislative work and in the scope of supervision”, he added. André Cheong was elected president of the AL on Friday and had the vote of all deputies, including his own. It was the first time, at least since 2019, that a deputy was unanimously elected president. The president of the AL also intends to implement greater cooperation between the Government and the hemicycle's technicians. “For important law proposals related to the well-being of the population, the Government needs considerable preparation time”, he indicated. "We hope to encourage AL technical teams to get involved earlier in the preparatory phase of government departments. For example, preliminary technical discussions and exchanges can result in more fluid technical communication when these important bills are being analyzed by the Legislative Assembly", he pointed out. Three desires After the start of the new Legislature, last Thursday, the Chief Executive held a meeting with deputies. On this occasion, according to the official version, given that the meeting took place behind closed doors, Sam Hou Fai told the legislators that he has three expectations for the functioning of the hemicycle. The first involves “further enhancing the leadership role of the Legislative Assembly in political terms”, in what he explained as a role in promoting nationalism and maintaining harmony in the long term. Secondly, he also asked deputies to “further enhance the role of the Legislative Assembly in drafting legislation and monitoring”, which he explained involved deputies “working together with the executive body” to create and review legislation considered key for the Executive, such as the diversification of the economy. Finally, the AL was asked to be a “fundamental interlocutor” in collecting opinions from “public opinion”, while also indicating that it expected deputies to guide “society to form an environment for positive, objective and rational discussion” and “promote the broadest possible social consensus to support the Macao SAR Government”.

item.title: LAG 2026 | Macau in a “key phase” of diversification, says secretary
item.description: The Secretary for Economy and Finance, Tai Kin Ip, recently met with several associations in order to obtain their opinions for the preparation of the Governing Action Lines (LAG) for next year. Quoted in an official note, Tai Kin Ip considered that “Macau is at a key stage in promoting economic diversification”, having promised, within the scope of these meetings, “to further optimize the business environment”. Another of the guarantees left by the government official refers to “support for small and medium-sized companies to improve their quality, stabilize local employment, create more development opportunities for residents and continually improve measures to guarantee the well-being of the population”. The General Association of Women of Macau, General Association of Fukien Countrymen of Macau, Macau Institution People's Alliance, General Union of Residents' Associations of Macau, Commercial Association of Macau, Industrial Association of Macau, Macau Youth Federation, Federation of Workers' Associations of Macau and General Association of Overseas Chinese of Macau met with Tai Kin Ip.

item.title: Government reformulation | Chan Tsz King admits he has little experience in the area
item.description: The new Secretary for Security, Chan Tsz King, admitted yesterday that he had little experience for the position he has held since yesterday, replacing Wong Sio Chak. “For me, this is a very big challenge because I have never had contact with the security area and have little experience in this area”, he said, according to statements reproduced by TDM. The new secretary highlighted the quality of the team he will work with, which has “experienced personnel”, namely the director general of the Customs Services and Unitary Police Services. Furthermore, Chan Tsz King highlighted that “the issue of national security is very important for Macau society”, awaiting “long-term developments and legal diplomas that are being produced”. Regarding the Lines of Government Action (LAG) for next year, for this guardianship, Chan Tsz King said that they are already being prepared. “For my part, the main thing is to adjust to this area and master the details.” Chan Tsz King was a commissioner of the Commissariat against Corruption (CCAC), between 2019 and 2024, but began his career in public service as a delegate of the Public Prosecutor's Office in 1997. He was then promoted to the position of deputy prosecutor in March 2000, having been seconded to carry out duties in the Public Prosecutor's Service at the Courts of Second and Final Instances from January 2012 to December 2019. The new Secretary for Security was born in Hong Kong in 1970 and has higher education completed in Portugal, namely at the Faculty of Arts of the University of Lisbon in Portugal, completed in 1989, and a Law course completed at the Autonomous University of Lisbon in Portugal in 1995. MP | Tong Hio Fong talks “great responsibility” Tong Hio Fong, who assumed the role of Public Prosecutor (MP) of the Macao SAR yesterday, as part of the government reform, thanked the “confidence of the Central Government and the Chief Executive” in assuming an “important and highly responsible position”. The official also added that he will “contribute to the development of the Macao SAR”, describing the territory as a successful example of the practice of one country, two systems, with “long-term stability and prosperity being ensured by the rule of law”. In turn, Tong Hio Fong said that the MP “is an important institution to defend the rule of law, being responsible for defending the dignity of the law, protecting the rights of citizens and combating illegal activities”. As Prosecutor, he promised to focus “on the principle of the rule of law, apply the law rigorously and fairly and strengthen inspection of judicial activities”, as well as “increase judicial efficiency”. Administration | Wong Sio Chak collects opinions on markets Upon assuming a vast portfolio, that of Administration and Justice, Wong Sio Chak, former Secretary for Security, promised that, in the coming weeks, he will listen to the population's opinions regarding the functioning of markets. "In the near future I will visit the communities, in particular the markets. I will continue to do this [listen to opinions]. The means to receive the public's opinions are always unimpeded", he told the press. To journalists, Wong Sio Chak thanked the work carried out by his predecessor, André Cheong, ensuring that he will now focus on four areas that he believes are priorities, such as the reform of Public Administration, strengthening the construction of “One country, two systems”, greater efficiency in governance and promoting integration in the Greater Bay Area and the Hengqin Deep Cooperation Zone. "Regardless of government or local services, it is easy to appear bad habits, such as sectarianism, bureaucracy or isolated actions. These situations also occur in Macau and we need to change that. We need to facilitate horizontal communication [within the Public Service] and increase the effectiveness of cooperation", he added. Wong Sio Chak argued that it is necessary to “increase staff capacity, explore their potential and make good use of talent, optimizing the allocation of employees”.
