In this way, the government official considers that “it is necessary to create more concrete training actions, especially in the capacity building of services”. Wong Sio Chak, was born in Guangdong province in 1968 and graduated in Law from Peking University. After a long career in the Judiciary Police, he was appointed Secretary for Security in 2014.

item.title: Populism has fallen into the well
item.description: André Ventura had announced that in the local elections he would win the presidency of around 30 councils. In 308, he obtained the “resounding” result of three Municipal Chambers. The polls that we unfortunately still have showed that victory would belong to AD, second place to Chega and third to the Socialist Party. Television commentators were full of praising the polls and pointing out that Chega's result would be normal because the PS had been in absolute decline since the last legislative elections. They were wrong, once again. Polls and commentators. The Socialist Party rose from the ashes and achieved a very positive result. Overall, they did not lose by much and in terms of results from parties alone, without coalitions, the socialists obtained almost twice as many Municipal Chambers as the PSD. It has been proven that without radical populism, without xenophobia, without racism and without the cries of André Ventura, Chega is a flop at a local level, especially in the interior of the country. Populism has fallen into the well and we will see when the “firefighters” can bring it to the surface. Chega won in Entroncamento without knowing exactly why, it won in a Madeiran town where half a dozen people live and it won in Albufeira because the owners of the bars and hotels managed to convince the entire clientele and neighborhood to vote for the neo-Nazis. The voters of Albufeira will cry drool and snot because Chega recommends in its Algarve program that bars close at two in the morning and the owners of these nightlife establishments demand that they close at four in the morning. Local discontent will prevail and will certainly translate into the next elections. This, in Albufeira, because in the rest of the Algarve Chega thought of winning everything. Not even that kind of tavern keeper who is always shouting in Parliament and wiping sweat from his bald head managed to win in Faro. The global map is divided between the AD/IL and the pink party. Cavakistan ended after several decades. You saw that there was always that Ruas, who dyes his hair and mustache wanting to look like he was 30 years old, he had a defeat like he never expected. In Lisbon and Porto, the case has already caused a lot of talk. The victories of AD and its Liberal Initiative counterparts in Lisbon, and in Porto with the verbal support of Rui Moreira, the mayor who ended his controversial mandates, were obtained by a minimal margin and until midnight on election Sunday the television stations were only talking about a technical draw. It was sad to see Luís Montenegro, in his capacity as prime minister versus president of the PSD, on election day calling for votes for his fellow candidates, going absolutely against the law. Montenegro claimed victory, but it could have been a little more humble because the municipal victory was tangential and lost many important Chambers such as Braga and Coimbra. The people, this time, showed great civic sense and abstention was one of the lowest in electoral history. At many polling stations the queues were huge and the wait was very long. It was the translation that abstention would download. Even so, the fraud did not cease to exist. In one region of the country, the old illegality of a party having had voting slips printed similar to those given to voters and then proposing that their appeased parties carry a ballot in their pocket with a cross in the party in question and when they brought the blank ballot that the polling station had delivered, they would receive two thousand euros. Not bad for a few thousand “mercenaries”. The people are fed up with elections, but nothing about the matter is going to end. The spearheads of the candidates for President of the Republic are already on the road. The variety is huge, but almost all in the same direction. On the center right we have Admiral Gouveia e Melo with Marques Mendes. Even further to the right appears the “bocas” André Ventura and Cotrim Figueiredo, who was leader of the Liberal Initiative. On the moderate left side, António José Seguro appeared and it was only last Saturday that the Socialist Party decided to officially support the candidate António José Seguro. Too late. And even so, the leftmost socialist wing will vote for António Filipe of the PCP, in the good style of Álvaro Cunhal, who suggested that sometimes you have to cover your eyes to vote for someone who doesn't belong to the party. This time, the polls seem to be getting it right. A polling company, in which we have the greatest confidence, obtained in a national survey carried out last week, that there will be a second round between Gouveia e Melo and António José Seguro. However, when the respondents were faced with the final decision in the second round, victory fell to the admiral. Because, just as we wrote last Monday, Luís Montenegro, with this municipal victory, will not resign, even if the Public Ministry opens a judicial inquiry against the current prime minister regarding the case of his family company Spinumviva. The man has been in politics for many years and knows everything about how to defend himself against suspicions of alleged scammers. Portugal will continue to be governed by a politician under serious suspicion, but that in no way affects his unhealthy desire to be head of the Executive.

item.title: What direction for Macau in 2026?
item.description: Only people from abroad will be surprised by the announcement of the list of seven deputies appointed by the Chief Executive to the 8th legislature of the Legislative Assembly. As one commentator highlighted, the personnel change is part of a “chess game”, aimed at further improving the constitutional structure with a predominance of the executive branch, under the principle of “One Country, Two Systems”, and at strengthening the functions of the administrative, legislative and judicial bodies, as well as deepening their constructive interaction. Given the effectiveness of the consultative policy that has long been in force in Macau, the chance of Cheong Weng Chon (appointed by the Chief Executive to be a deputy of the Legislative Assembly) being elected President or Vice-President of the 8th legislature of the Legislative Assembly on October 16th, in the first session of the Plenary, is very high. It is difficult to imagine how Cheong, who was Secretary for Administration and Justice, could avoid embarrassing situations in the upcoming sectoral debates on the Lines of Government Action, especially when they focus on the area of ​​administration and justice, if he simply limited himself to being a deputy. If elected President of the Assembly, embarrassing situations can be avoided. The three former Chief Executives of Macau, Ho Hau Wah, Chui Sai On and Ho Iat Seng, were all part of the Legislative Assembly. Ho Iat Seng, with his experience as President of the Assembly, understood very well the type of problems generated in administrative departments. After taking office as Chief Executive, Ho actually carried out in-depth work to optimize the efficiency of the administrative structure. After Macau's return to Chinese sovereignty, Cheong Weng Chon was Director of the Justice Affairs Bureau, Commissioner against Corruption, Secretary for Administration and Justice and Head of the Executive Committee of the Guangdong-Macao In-depth Cooperation Zone in Hengqin, so he is well versed in administrative matters. His frequent interactions with the Legislative Assembly during the law-making process allowed him to gain a good understanding of the capabilities and performance of deputies. If Cheong leads the 8th term of the Legislative Assembly, he will undoubtedly set a precedent for the full realization of the predominance of the executive branch under the principle of “One Country, Two Systems”. Macau, a small city with about 700,000 inhabitants and an area of ​​33.3 square kilometers, was entrusted with the task of transforming the In-depth Cooperation Zone between Guangdong and Macau on Hengqin Island, into the new trade center of the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area and the new platform for China's opening up to the outside world. As long as annual gaming revenue can remain at MOP240 billion, the SAR Government can make ends meet and provide for the basic needs of Macau residents. The problems facing public servants and small and medium-sized businesses can be resolved. A focus is needed on creating an environment that promotes business in public spaces, developing more employment opportunities for residents and investing in economic construction. The direction Macau will take in 2026 will be influenced by changes in neighboring areas. Barring unforeseen circumstances, Sanae Takaichi, who follows in the footsteps of former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, will be the first woman to hold that position and will be elected at an extraordinary session of the Japanese Diet called for October 15. News indicates that US President Donald Trump will visit Japan between October 27th and 29th to meet with the Emperor and the new Prime Minister. Furthermore, the fourth plenary session of the 20th. Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) will take place in Beijing from October 20th to 23rd. This chain of interactions, which was certainly not planned, suggests the inerception of a powerful hand. At the reception commemorating the 80th anniversary of China's victory in the War of Resistance against Japanese Aggression, President Xi Jinping stated that China is a force for world peace. If this strength comes into play, Macau can still sail smoothly into 2026.

item.title: In Memoriam by Chef António Coelho
item.description: “I love Portuguese food. I love the traditional and authentic cuisine. It’s the one I learned in Portugal. For me, that’s very important because I prefer the traditional things.” Chef António Neves Coelho The guardian of Portuguese-Macanese cuisine and dear friend, Chef António das Neves Coelho, left us on October 12, 2025, at Hospital Conde de São Januário. Major figure of Portuguese gastronomy in Macau, mentor to generations, defender of culinary authenticity and symbol of institutional resilience. His departure represents an irreparable loss for the gastronomic culture of the Macao SAR and for the emotional memory of all who shared his table, kitchen and dreams with him. Chef António grew up amidst the aromas of olive oil, garlic and red wine. From an early age, he revealed a rare vocation for cooking, not just as a technique, but as a cultural narrative. His training took place in emblematic houses of Portuguese gastronomy, where he learned to respect the ingredients, times and affections that make up the culinary tradition. His international career took him to three continents and, finally, to Macau, where he completed his military service and found his true stage. From 1997 onwards, he established himself as Executive Chef and operations manager in reference spaces, becoming one of the main ambassadors of Portuguese and Macanese cuisine. Macau was not only his professional destination but his spiritual home. António understood that Macanese cuisine is not just a fusion of flavors, but also of stories. With sensitivity and rigor, he became a defender of the preservation of traditional recipes, the valorization of local ingredients and the formation of multicultural teams with a spirit of mission. He founded his own brand, where he worked as culinary director and general manager for more than a decade at António Restaurante, receiving 12 Michelin recommendations, among others. His leadership was marked by a rare combination of technical demands, human empathy and strategic vision. His cuisine was made of olive oil and affection, of technique and tenderness, of rigor and poetry. Its contribution was recognized by two highly prestigious distinctions such as the Medal of Tourist Merit, awarded by the Government of the Macao SAR, in recognition of its role in the development of the hospitality sector and local gastronomic culture and the Medal of Merit of Portuguese Communities, awarded by the Government of Portugal, for its action as a cultural bridge between continents and for the promotion of Portuguese identity abroad. These honors were not just trophies but testimonies of his dedication to the public cause, culture and excellence. In 2024, Chef António took on the leadership of a new gastronomic project at Angela Café & Lounge at Lisboeta Macau. There, he created a menu that celebrated the Portuguese and Macanese essence, with dishes such as codfish à lagareiro, seafood rice and desserts with a conventual touch. The space has become a meeting point between tradition and modernity, between tourists and locals, between memory and the future. His team, formed and inspired by him, continues to represent the pillars of his vision with dedication, creativity and commitment to excellence. Chef António's death represents a human and institutional loss of great significance. But his legacy remains alive in the memory of the customers who tasted his dishes; in the training of professionals who learned from him; in the institutional identity of the spaces he helped to build and in the gastronomic culture of Macau and the Portuguese diaspora His work does not end with his departure but continues in each preserved recipe, in each technical gesture transmitted and in each ethical value defended. More than a Chef, António was the guardian of the Portuguese-Macanese gastronomic soul. His life was a bridge between continents, flavors and generations. His cuisine was made of memory and innovation, of technique and tenderness, of rigor and poetry. May his memory continue to live on in every dish served, in every story told and in every young professional who dares to dream of a cuisine that respects the past and transforms the present. Before his departure, Chef António left his legatee a precious set of recipes that are not mere technical records, but authentic trophies of Portuguese cuisine, honed over decades of practice, reflection and passion. This legacy is not just a gastronomic collection but a cultural heritage, a letter of intent and a mission to fulfill. Each recipe represents a chapter of your life, a shared memory, a silent tribute to the roots that formed you. These are dishes that carry the flavor of childhood, the rigor of classical training, the boldness of reinvention and the tenderness of maturity. These are formulas that are not limited to ingredients and quantities as they contain gestures, silences, waiting times, and above all, intention. The legatee, chosen with discernment and trust, did not just receive a recipe book. He received a culinary testament, a map of values ​​and institutional responsibility. It will now be up to you to execute, preserve and reinterpret these creations with fidelity and courage, keeping the flame of authenticity alive without falling into the rigidity of repetition. In the Portuguese tradition, the transmission of recipes is an act of intimacy and respect. It's not just about teaching but about trust. Chef António understood this deeply. For this reason, the recipes he left were not disseminated en masse, nor transformed into a commercial product. They were given to those who knew how to understand his spirit, to those who shared his daily kitchen with him and to those who demonstrated technical ability and human sensitivity. These recipes include classic dishes and conventual desserts reinterpreted with local ingredients. But they also include new creations, designed for special occasions, themed menus and cultural tributes. These are dishes that never reached the public, but that can now be revealed with the care they deserve. Executing these recipes is not just reproducing flavors but embodying a philosophy. The legatee will have to maintain a balance between fidelity and evolution, technique and emotion, tradition and contemporaneity. You will have to respect the times, the gestures, the silences that Chef António taught. You will have to understand that each dish is also a message, a memory and an affirmation of identity. More than cooking, it will have to cure in a museological and emotional sense. Curate the legacy, protect it from trivialization and present it with dignity. You will have to train others, transmit the values ​​you received, ensure that the legacy does not disappear over time, but multiplies with meaning. This work is not just gastronomic but curatorial, educational and diplomatic. It is a way of affirming that cuisine is also culture, that the dish is also a document and that the flavor is also memory. The recipes left by Chef António are seeds. It is now up to the legatee and the institution involved to cultivate them with respect, water them with knowledge and make them flourish with creativity. Each time one of these recipes is served, it will be as if Chef António were present not as a shadow, but as a light. This legacy is a rare gift. And like any precious gift, it requires care, time and love. May it be honored with the same generosity with which it was conceived. May it be shared with the same elegance with which it was lived. May it be perpetuated with the same passion with which it was created. Because in the kitchen, as in life, what remains is not what is repeated, it is what is respected.

item.title: Sex and emotions
item.description: Sex can awaken a range of emotions. From positive to negative — including neutral — emotions often emerge in a haphazard way, without us being able to give them immediate meaning. There are those who even experience emotional combinations that place side by side emotions that at first glance would be opposites: pleasure and shame. These responses, however, are culturally shaped. Sex, deep down, is a microcosm of human emotional life, where body, culture and identity intersect. Attachment theory, often described as the theory of love, shows how the search for security, or its absence, shapes our emotional response in relationships with others. The body has hormonal mechanisms associated with pleasure, which make us feel safe, but also others that can perpetuate our sense of insecurity. The way emotional responses are created depends largely on context and our past experiences. Therefore, emotions often become a lens through which we look at the world. The psychology of emotions has crossed two important lineages to understand these mechanisms. One of them is medicine, where emotion results from physiological construction and regulation. The other comes from anthropology, which has explored how culture shapes our emotional responses. For example, intercultural studies have shown that in more individualistic societies, where anger is a form of expression of breaking relationships with others – in an attempt to impose limits – the physiological response is stronger than in collectivist societies. In societies where the group configuration has a more determining weight on the sense of self, anger is just an indicator that there is disharmony in the group relationship, and the physiological response and inflammation levels are lower. Anger is not perceived as a radical break from the collective, and therefore the experience of anger is, in some way, more sustained. This cultural dimension becomes even more evident when we analyze the way in which various gender expressions construct their emotional worlds. Although popular culture tells us that there are differences between 'men' and 'women', the truth is that there is much more variability within each group than between them, which makes it difficult to justify a clear distinction. This division is culturally fueled and manifests itself in everyday gestures. Studies show that when women arrive at an emergency room with palpitations, they are more quickly diagnosed with anxiety than with a heart attack. The same does not happen with men, from whom a lesser emotional manifestation is expected, and therefore symptoms such as palpitations are rarely confused with anxiety. Thus, it becomes almost expected for women to express excessive emotions and for men to repress them — which distorts our notion of what is ‘normal’ or ‘deviant’. It is worth bringing here an essential distinction in the theory of emotions: there are primary emotions, which are more immediate and more faithful to our internal states, and secondary emotions, which are in some way a complexification of the first, fed by beliefs, narratives and cultures. If at a certain moment I feel angry, and if my life experience has taught me that anger is an inappropriate emotion, other emotions quickly take over, such as shame or guilt. All of this is relevant to better understanding emotions during sex. In the reductive binarism of custom, generalist beliefs persist that impose performance pressure on men and feelings of guilt on women — dynamics that are also reflected in same-sex relationships. When we realize that the emotions that emerge do not correspond to what culture defines as 'normal', we begin to monitor and censor what we feel. Without a deep understanding of emotions, the body and the context in which they are inserted, we end up complicating our lives. For example, the emotions that follow sex vary as much as the experiences themselves. Some feel a peaceful well-being, a feeling of closeness and tenderness — the so-called afterglow. Others experience the opposite: a certain melancholy or emptiness, known as post-sex dysphoria. These emotional states seem to depend less on the physical act and more on the meaning that each person attributes to it — connection, validation, curiosity or loneliness. Emotions are closely linked to the meanings we attribute to things. It is the deeper conversations about emotions that free us from the artificial limits that prevent full emotional honesty. Only by understanding these processes — which translate social contexts and cultural narratives into physiological and emotional responses that the body carries — can we better understand sex, its pleasures and its difficulties. And if we treat sex as a conversation between bodies and emotions — perhaps we can listen to ourselves, and others, with more presence and empathy.

item.title: Agualusa says that a bad writer will never write a good book
item.description: A bad writer “will never write a good novel using artificial intelligence”, said writer José Eduardo Agualusa this Saturday at FOLIO – Óbidos International Literary Festival, arguing that this instrument does not pose a danger to authors and may even have some potential. “I believe that a bad writer will never write a good novel using artificial intelligence”, but “perhaps a good writer will be able to write a better novel once he knows how to use this instrument”, he added. At a panel of authors in which he assured that artificial intelligence does not scare him, the Angolan writer considered that this instrument “is still used in a trivial way” by many people, but that when “if you know how to use it well, you will probably discover greater potential”. Even so, he considers that there is no danger of “writers being replaced”, because artificial intelligence “mimics, reproduces the writer’s style”, but “the imitation of the style is normally ridiculous”. In other chapters “that instrument is very useful”, he said, giving as an example the Angolan chronicle in the newspapers, which “improved a lot, because it corrects very well”. “In the case of Angola it is very clear, suddenly the chroniclers started to write better, any emergency we ask for and the weekly column comes out”. However, in the long narrative, in the novel, “the AI ​​still has a big challenge” and, even if one day it manages to write “a mediocre novel” it will have to have “someone behind it, with creativity”. Conversations on FOLIO José Eduardo Agualusa spoke at the 12th panel of FOLIO, in a conversation with Brazilian writer Giovana Madalosso, where both argued that literature is not in danger, despite movements of censorship and cancellation of writers in countries like Brazil. Because “more and more people are reading. More and more people are reading better”, said Agualusa. The FOLIO ended yesterday. This year marked the tenth year of existence with more than 460 initiatives, including more than a hundred conversations between authors and the public, 15 author tables, gatherings, seminars, book launches, concerts and prize giving.

item.title: UPM | Creative Macau hosts exhibition with student works
item.description: The Creative Macau gallery hosts, until November 8th, the exhibition “Prototype – Exhibition of Works by Students of the Degree in Media Arts”, from the Macau Polytechnic University. There are 30 works by more than 20 students who attend this course and who show all their creativity here Creative Macau hosts a new exhibition composed of works of art by students from the Macau Polytechnic University. This is “Prototype” – Exhibition of Works by Students of the Degree Course in Media Arts at the Macau Polytechnic University (UPM) 2025″, and can be seen until November 8th, with free entry. The exhibition presents more than 30 works of art by around 20 students who attend the degree program at UPM, with the public being able to see “a curated selection of notable works by students from the first to the third year” of the aforementioned course, explains a note from Creative Macau. You will be able to see a “diversity of work, ranging from interactive digital experiences to physical creations, reflecting the program's balanced emphasis on both theoretical foundations and practical application”. Thus, “through practical work in various courses, students acquired proficiency in a wide range of design tools and production techniques, transforming abstract ideas into fully realized works.” “Important milestone” Creative Macau further describes that this exhibition, and the opportunity that students have to show the results of their work, “constitutes an important milestone in their academic journey”. “By sharing these creations with the public, we hope to stimulate a broader dialogue and exchange about media arts, emerging technologies and the cultural future they continue to shape”, it is further stated. Creative Macau – Creative Industries Center was founded in 2003 and has been managed by the Macau Institute of European Studies. Over the years, Creative Macau has supported projects and artistic works in 12 areas of the creative industries, including advertising, architecture, design, fashion or crafts. “Its objective is to help these industries reach their full economic potential, adding value and promoting recognition in society”, it is further described. In the case of the degree in Media Arts at UPM, the objective is to “train high-quality media arts professionals through a curriculum that emphasizes multidisciplinary learning in the areas of arts, design and technology”. The aim here is that “students develop communication skills, international vision, intercultural understanding and innovative thinking, while at the same time acquiring knowledge and skills in media arts in the areas of interaction in games, technological art and video storytelling”.

item.title: Brazilian writer Ozias Filho talks about the role of literature
item.description: Brazilian writer Ozias Filho stated on Friday that literature is a political and resistance act and that poetry produced by artificial intelligence will never be equal, because it lacks the “intangible and irreplaceable” experience. Ozias Filho was speaking during the XIII Meeting of Portuguese Language Writers, which ran until Saturday in the Cape Verdean capital, in a panel dedicated to literature and development. The photographer and book editor, who was born in Rio de Janeiro, but has lived in Portugal for several years, stated that today we are experiencing “a remarkable paradox: we have never had so much access to information, but never, on the other hand, have we been so exposed to disorder and manipulation”. “Fake news, the algorithms that shape our perception and the ephemeral nature of digital interactions have transformed language into a true battlefield,” he said. For Ozias Filho, literature is “an act of resistance against any power instituted by force, a weapon for the conscience that, once awakened, will no longer remain silent”. "Reading is apprehending the world and understanding its context. And it is not enough to live in a dictatorship to understand the meaning of this thought", he stated. In Ozias Filho's opinion, today we live “under the aegis of the dictatorship of immediacy, consumerism, lies and historical revisionism”. “It is no coincidence that reading, learning, education and culture are often devalued in dictatorial regimes”, he observed, adding: “Even when reading is encouraged in these systems, it is because it fulfills and conveys the ideology of the current power”. Artificial poetry Ozias Filho then addressed one of the themes of this meeting of writers in his speech, artificial intelligence, asking the question: “Can a machine create poetry?”. "Yes, artificial intelligence is capable of producing metered verses, coherent metaphors and even poems that move. It can reproduce the form, but it lacks something intangible and irreplaceable: experience." And he concluded that "an algorithm does not feel grief, loss, does not know resistance, does not experience passion or longing, nor does it fight against oppression. It can simulate, but it will never possess the soul, the result of a singular, imperfect and contradictory human experience." Teresa Moure, from Galicia, Joaquim Ng Pereira (Macau/China), Daniel Medina and Vera Duarte, both from Cape Verde, also participated in this panel. The meeting began with the presentation of the UCCLA-Lisbon City Council Literary Revelation Award, this year awarded to actor Cláudio da Silva, who was born in Angola and lives in Portugal. The presentation was given by Germano de Almeida, the Cape Verdean writer who won the Camões Prize in 2018.

item.title: Photography | Gonçalo Lobo Pinheiro distinguished at Budapest International Photo
item.description: Portuguese photojournalist Gonçalo Lobo Pinheiro, based in Macau for over 15 years, was awarded the Gold award in the Editorial/Political category of the prestigious Budapest International Foto Awards (BIFA), with a photo report on the visit of the President of the People's Republic of China, Xi Jinping, to Macau, during the celebrations of the 25th anniversary of the MSAR. Created for Agência Lusa, the photographic series documents key moments of the presidential visit, with images that capture the solemn atmosphere of the official ceremonies and the political symbolism of the occasion. "I am very happy with this achievement. This photographic series documents key moments of President Xi Jinping's visit to Macau to mark the 25th anniversary of the MSAR. With images of the President and the authorities who accompanied him, the report portrays the formal atmosphere of the celebrations, highlighting the political weight of the visit", said the photojournalist, former editor of HM, quoted in a statement. The photographs, marked by rigorous framing and close observation, reveal the choreography of State protocol, the symbolism of unity and the persistent ties between Macau and mainland China at this historical moment. “Through careful compositions and a close look, I sought to reflect the ceremonial staging and the importance of the moment for Macau and its relationship with Beijing.” The award reinforces the international recognition of press photography produced in Macau and highlights the fundamental role of photojournalism in documenting political events of global importance, highlights the same note.

item.title: Fengshen | Typhoon expected to pass 400km from Macau
item.description: Tropical cyclone Fengshen is expected to pass around 400 kilometers south of Macau on Wednesday, according to the Meteorological and Geophysical Services Directorate (DSMG). At that time, according to yesterday's forecasts, the tropical cyclone should gain strength and transform into a typhoon. “Therefore, depending on the development of Fengshen and changes in wind strength in Macau, a Tropical Storm Signal will be issued from Monday night (today)”, it was pointed out. Since yesterday, it was also predicted that the wind would begin to intensify due to “a northeast monsoon”, and authorities believed that there would be a “significant increase, with the wind reaching levels 6 to 7 on the Beaufort Scale”. Temperatures | Descent to 18 degrees From today until Wednesday, temperatures are expected to drop to 18 degrees, according to information released yesterday by the Directorate of Meteorological and Geophysical Services (DSMG). “Regarding the weather, precipitation is expected, with the minimum temperature dropping to around 18 degrees Celsius, between Monday and Wednesday (20 to 22)”, it was indicated. "Due to the significant drop in temperatures next week, and the strong wind associated with cloudy weather with precipitation, the thermal sensation of cold will be lower than the actual temperature. DSMG urges the population to pay attention to the most recent meteorological information", it was added.

item.title: Caritas | More than 3,500 requests for help received by the end of September
item.description: The number of support requests shows a stabilization trend in recent years. And given the lack of “very serious” poverty problems, Cáritas Macau also extended its support program to Pakistan and Bangladesh Cáritas Macau received 3,509 requests for support for the Food Bank by the end of September, the organization's secretary-general said yesterday, indicating that this year's final values ​​should not differ from those of 2024. “We expect it [in 2025] to exceed four thousand, like last year”, noted Paul Pun Chi Meng to Lusa, pointing out that, in 2024, 4,936 requests reached the humanitarian organization, which, in turn, represents a drop of 2.5 percent compared to 2023 (5,065). In an annual comparison, the first nine months of 2025 present values ​​similar to those recorded in the same period of 2023 and 2024: 3,589 and 3,596, respectively. Even so, there is a slight decline this year, which could be related to the “existence of other support resources” or “greater ease in applying for social housing”, noted Pun, implying that easier access to public housing could ease the bills at the end of the month. The program, aimed at low-income people and financed by the authorities, foresees that the Bank's support will result in food aid for a period of ten weeks, with a second request being possible within 12 months. Among non-resident workers, highlighted Paul Pun, there is also a group that uses social assistance organizations. Last Saturday, close to a thousand people received support in the form of food baskets. Aid in Pakistan and Bangladesh The secretary general of Cáritas also explained that as Macau does not face “very serious poverty” problems, the organization is supporting disadvantaged families in Bangladesh and Pakistan, providing aid to 2,100 people. Last week, Pun returned from Sylhet, a city in northeastern Bangladesh that he has visited several times since 2023, the year in which Cáritas Macau became involved in a program to “improve the health and nutrition of disadvantaged children”. With donations of around 15 thousand dollars per year, aid has already reached 400 people, said the person in charge. “We hope that, through training, in terms of care for newborns, mothers, they can achieve a better life”, pointed out the general secretary of Cáritas Macau, also noting that, on the table is the possibility of providing resources for the professional training of teenagers who dropped out of school. About a month ago, Paul Pun was also in Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan, with nearly 14 million inhabitants and which has been affected, in recent years, by several floods. Cáritas Macau's assistance to the “Informal education and development of young people and women” program, with the transfer of up to 35 thousand dollars per year (around 30 thousand euros), has already touched the lives of 1,200 children and 500 teenagers in Lahore, according to the leader of the humanitarian organization. "The children do not have schools [in these places]. They participate in this informal education program so that they have an opportunity to reach the standards and one day be able to enter school", he said. In addition to supporting the education of teenagers – “especially boys” – in areas such as IT, the program also includes skills training “by young women”. To Lusa, Paul Pun said that international assistance from Cáritas Macau arrives “via several channels”, namely through donations and the organization Good Fortune Charity Shop, the social enterprise of Cáritas Macau, which collects donated goods for charitable sale.

item.title: UM joins the UNESCO Chair dedicated to Portuguese heritage
item.description: The University of Macau (UM) announced its membership of the UNESCO Chair in Intercultural Dialogue on Heritage of Portuguese Influence, a project launched by the University of Coimbra (UC). In a statement released on Friday night, UM argued that joining the project “imposes a new dynamic in the development of research on cultural heritage” in Macau. The collaboration with UC will promote “international academic exchange in Macau”, as well as strengthen “ties” with higher education institutions in Portuguese-speaking countries, UM added. The institution's formal accession to the UNESCO Chair took place in a ceremony organized by the two institutions in Macau, on Wednesday, with the presence of Rui Martins, vice-rector of UM, and João Nuno Calvão da Silva, vice-rector of UC. Rui Martins argued that UM's entry “will further enrich the academic resources and cultural perspective” of the already “wide network of partners” established by the UNESCO Chair. The UC created the project in 2018, to explore “the multicultural results resulting from the influence of Portuguese-speaking culture”, such as architecture, arts, language, literature, landscape and urbanism, said the statement. At the time, the UNESCO Chair already involved fifty teachers and researchers in a partnership with several European, Brazilian and African institutions. Comprehensive effort The list included the University of Bologna Studies (Italy), the Universidade Federal Fluminense (Brazil), the universities Eduardo Mondlane and Lúrio (Mozambique), the University Paris Nanterre (France) and MEIA – Mindelo Escola Internacional de Arte (Cape Verde). Rui Martins, a Portuguese academic who has long lived in Macau, highlighted that the UNESCO Chair is an international project “that integrates research, training and cooperation for development”. In the case of UM, the Department of Integrated Resorts and Tourism Management of the Faculty of Business Management will “actively demonstrate its professional competence” in research into cultural heritage, guaranteed Martins. The UNESCO Chair is coordinated by researcher Walter Rossa, who on Wednesday spoke about “the political significance” of research on cultural heritage within the organization's policies.

item.title: Justice | Portugal may send new judges to Macau
item.description: Despite having prevented Carlos Carvalho from remaining in the territory and maintaining uncertainty about the future of Rui Ribeiro, who chose to return to Portugal, the Superior Council of the Judiciary of Portugal guarantees openness to sending new magistrates to the Macao SAR The president of the Supreme Court of Justice (STJ) stated that Portugal is available, if Macau shows interest, in sending new judges. The statements were made at a time when a Portuguese magistrate is about to leave the Macao SAR. Judge Rui Ribeiro, of the Court of Second Instance, confirmed to Lusa, on the sidelines of a public event, that he will leave Macau at the end of October, bringing forward the end of the commission, which ended in May 2026. The magistrate stressed that the Macau judicial authorities “did everything” to make him change his mind, but explained that he preferred to return to Portugal now given the uncertainty regarding a possible renewal of the special license by the Superior Council of Judiciary (CSM). With the announced departure of Rui Ribeiro, only one Portuguese judge remains in the Macau courts: Jerónimo Alberto Gonçalves Santos, president of a collective court at the Base Judicial Court (TJB). The leader of the STJ, João Cura Mariano, who inherently also presides over the CSM, told journalists that, during a visit to Macau, he wanted to find out if the territory was interested in having Portuguese magistrates. “We are going to try to see what they can really convey that is useful and whether they are necessary, because if they are necessary, new judges will come”, he assured the journalists. João Cura Mariano said that this would be a “subject to discuss” in yesterday's meetings with the president of the Court of Final Instance (TUI), Song Man Lei, and with Sam Hou Fai, leader of the Macau Government and former president of the TUI. “I think it is very useful, because, being a former president of the court [Sam Hou Fai] he will be aware of the needs that exist”, said the Portuguese judge advisor. National difficulties But the president of the STJ highlighted that Portuguese justice is having “some difficulty in contributing judges”, due to the lack of qualified and experienced human resources. “Just now we removed a judge who had been here for many years and we needed him”, recalled João Cura Mariano. In 2024, the CSM rejected the stay of Portuguese TJB judge Carlos Carvalho, who had been in Macau for 16 years and had been invited by the Independent Commission for the Nomination of Judges in the territory to continue for another two years. The council did not authorize the renewal of Carlos Carvalho's special license and promoted him to judge, with placement at the Court of Appeal. Even so, João Cura Mariano assured that he was willing to help, “despite the difficulties that currently exist in Portugal in recruiting judges”. The president of the STJ highlighted the example of Timor-Leste, where there are currently “many Portuguese judges collaborating in the Timorese judicial system”, because “they are very necessary”. The judge was in Macau to participate, on Sunday, in the 13th edition of the forum that brings together presidents of the Supreme Courts of Justice of Portuguese-speaking countries and territories.

item.title: São Januário | First artificial heart implanted in Macau
item.description: The first surgery to implant an artificial heart was recently carried out at the Conde de São Januário Hospital Center (CHCSJ) of Health Services (SS), in collaboration with the cardiothoracic surgery team of the First Affiliated Hospital of Jinan University. The procedure was carried out on a 68-year-old woman who suffered from terminal heart failure, and, according to a statement from the SS, “the condition presented was complex and the surgical intervention challenging”. It was “the first surgical procedure to implant a completely magnetically levitated artificial heart, developed autonomously in Mainland China”. Carrying out this surgery in the territory represents, for the authorities, “significant progress in cardiac surgery in Macau”. For the SS, “the successful completion of the first artificial heart implant surgery in Macau represents a significant advance in the treatment of terminal heart failure in the region”, in addition to this technological advance “fills a significant gap in medical care, offering a viable and safe alternative for patients who are not eligible for heart transplantation or who cannot wait for a surgical intervention”.

item.title: Fire leads to two hospitalizations and evacuation of 50 people
item.description: Two people had to be admitted to Kiang Wu Hospital, after a fire broke out on Wednesday night, in the Si Keng Building, on Rua da Alegria. In addition to the injured, there was also a need to remove 50 residents from the building, according to information released yesterday by the newspaper Ou Mun. Those hospitalized are two residents aged around 60, one male and one female, who reportedly showed signs of being unwell after inhaling smoke from the fire. Despite their indisposition, their clinical situation was considered stable. The remaining residents also managed to leave the building by their own means and did not present any type of discomfort or injuries. The flames began to break out at around 11:44 pm, when authorities were alerted to the situation. The arrival at the scene of both the Fire Department (CB) and the Public Security Police Corps (CPSP) took place minutes later, at a time when several of the building's inhabitants were already on the street. At the scene, firefighters had to climb to the third floor, where the fire originated. Fighting the flames took a few minutes. Traces indicate that the flames broke out next to a vase with flowers, and then reached the living room of the apartment on the third floor. During the fight against the fire, authorities closed Rua da Alegria and Estrada do Repouso to traffic for several minutes. Firefighters used water to fight the fire, which resulted in a burned area measuring 2.5 meters long and 1 meter wide. From the origins According to the newspaper Ou Mun, the CB suspects that the flames originated from a short circuit in a washing machine, positioned next to the vase with flowers. In addition to the burned area, the washing machine, a purifier, an air conditioner and other appliances and goods were also destroyed. According to the most recent data, in the first six months of the year, the CB was called to intervene in 406 fires. Among these, firefighters had to use hoses to extinguish the flames on 85 occasions. In the remaining 321 fires, the flames were extinguished without using a hose. Official information also revealed that 78 of the 406 fires originated from burnt food.

item.title: Hengqin | Portuguese restaurant opens across the border
item.description: It’s called “Vivo” and it’s a Mediterranean cuisine restaurant that opens its doors tomorrow in Hengqin. João Maria Pegado, one of the project's partners and previously linked to sport, is now focusing on the restaurant sector and has high expectations given the tourist demand on the island. A Mediterranean cuisine restaurant officially opens tomorrow in Hengqin. Located in the Huafa shopping center, the Vivo restaurant is a project by two Portuguese people who saw an opportunity to bring two geographies closer together – China and southern Europe. It's not about fusion cuisine. Still, several traditions coexist in this restaurant: Portuguese, Spanish and Italian cuisine, prepared by a chef from Shanghai with Chinese raw materials. “We are in China, we want to invest in fresh Chinese products”, one of the partners, João Maria Pegado, tells Lusa. So much so that, for now, there is no traditional octopus à lagareiro on the menu. You have to continue browsing local markets until you find the ideal product, explains Pegado. "We could go to Macau to get frozen octopus, but our main objective was to work with fresh products in China. In terms of cost, it makes it much more profitable, but we also want to take advantage and create this fusion between Chinese products and Portuguese dishes", he says. Vivo has been in ‘soft opening’ mode since July 18th. And João Maria Pegado does not complain about the journey he has taken so far, despite the difficulty of the language. More and more To Lusa, Pegado says he will soon compete for support from the Macau Government, at a time when authorities are encouraging investment in the Macau-Guangdong Deep Cooperation Zone, in Hengqin. And this region attracts more and more visitors to Macau, says the investor. In this area managed by both sides of the border, the movement of drivers from Macau is now permitted, for example, upon request for a license, recalls Pegado. But there are other attractions: gasoline is cheaper – “the cars in Macau come to fill up at the weekend, we [Portuguese] are like in Badajoz” – supermarkets are more affordable, more space and more green areas. "An open space where you can relax without being in the middle of the city. That's the big reason why people leave Macau for Hengqin on the weekend and sometimes even during the week, at lunchtime", he reflects. Hengqin also seems to be a more economical option for Chinese people visiting Macau, where, according to data for August, the average price of a hotel room is 1,461 patacas. "Hengqin has increasingly become a point of concentration, of sleeping, used by many visitors. Many of the buildings that were built as offices, the Government gave licenses (…) to build Airbnb-style hotels [local accommodation]", he said. Hong Kong and Macau are, for now, the origin of the majority of the restaurant's visitors, but João Maria Pegado also hopes to reach more consumers from the interior of China. “There are still few people who know what Mediterranean [the concept] means”, he highlights, noting, however, that, for many of those who have visited Vivo, black paella has been a recurring choice. This dish is joined by other specialties of the house, such as fisherman's rice, guilloche prawns or barbecue chicken, says Pegado, who left a career linked to sport to dedicate himself to the restaurant business. “It’s special”, he admits. “I felt that there was a lack of a Western food restaurant, and that it could be successful in that area (…). I have lived in Hengqin for three years and it is a place that I really appreciate, it allows me to be close to Macau, the city where I grew up and with which I feel identified”, he concludes.

item.title: ZELENSKY VS ZELENSKY
item.description:
10/27/22 A Ukrainian pensioner, with the same name as the president, blames Zelensky for the prolongation of the conflict that destroyed his village. Zelensky, the villager, who never left his land, is now mortified because his favorite gravedigger died in the bomber. This Zelensky, a villager, represents half the world that recriminates the other Zelensky, the villain, for not wanting to negotiate with Putin. Negotiate what? The invader enters our house, covers his wife and daughter (cf. recent UN report on the rapes in Ukraine, in this “special operation”), an act that forced us to watch, and then we say to him: hi there, we are for peace, but we have to negotiate: you still haven't said what name you want to give the children! A peace that is not dignified is nothing more than a cessation of rights. As serious as the Russophobia that Putin inflicts on his people.
10/28/22 At a lunch with several guests, I heard a friend, who declared herself a spiritualist, explaining the particularities of her belief, in a calm and balanced way, I would even say, without a hint of “irrationalism”. He spoke at length and serenely, devoid of any fanatical proselytism. “Here is someone whose belief has brought thoughtfulness!” I thought, a rare alliance. However, at a certain moment a sentence comes out that horrifies me. It says, “there is no chance, nothing happens by chance!”, and I glimpse the voracious maws of holism. Because holism has a pathological aspect, like all good things, a shadow side. Two examples: in Hinduism there is less sensitivity to existential dramas, if that child suffers in this life this is just an expression of rigorous karmic symmetry, an effect of the acts he committed in his previous life. In Africa, it is not accepted that death could have been accidental, and many women are accused by the family of the deceased of having caused the death of their husband, in an act of manifest dementia, and, in the blatant majority of cases, a huge injustice for the wife — madness that spreads and infiltrates the social fabric. Buddhism introduced Compassion and Christianity introduced Caritas, trying to break with this logic, but in many other beliefs and religions the cage of causalities prevails over sensitivity to experience, the need to respond to the now. It is a tremendous logic that transforms the world into a Platonic stage, where we are nothing more than the shadows of something — an inextricable law -, in a determinism that calcifies all singularities, but that strangely fascinates many. The conquest of modernity was anchored in the conquest of chance and randomness, removing the incidences of a life from this fierce determinism that enclosed the world in a web. When the Renaissance freed the body from the influence of the stars, at that moment sexuality was relieved of guilt and individualism and its volition were able to emerge. There is an unequivocal moral implication in the phrase “there is no such thing as chance, nothing happens by chance!”, which should function as a key to self-knowledge and self-judgment, however, this phrase is usually used to seek a reason for things outside of us, in others. It's an alibi. Today there is a holistic temptation in the world, just as there was a satanic temptation in the Middle Ages, without much reflection on its consequences. Because it's not enough to want to connect everything in a resonant chain of affection. Even for the most unexpected: affection itself can kill. I realize, thanks to that cultured, balanced, intelligent woman, that “the fight” took place at the beginning of this century. One of the great mistakes of the 20th century was the false dichotomy between “rationalism and irrationalism”, a debate that extended to all fields, including art. First, rationality (the positive side of reason) was confused with rationalism (the pathological aspect of reason), and articulated in this lack of discernment, irrationalism was confused with freedom. Almost all 20th century art, with Surrealism at its head, made this mistake. The fallacy still exists despite the emergence of “irrationalism” and the consequent relativist currents that followed it having been consolidated everywhere. Essentially, much of what happened in the 20th century revolved around this clash between two paradigms: Rationalism versus Irationalism. Now, I see, we must save indeterminacy, chance, randomness from the terrible temptation of the cage of causalities. Holism, in its pathological form, may be reductionism that sets itself up as a new “eschatological narrative”. Is it “by chance” that holism emerges at a time when neo-liberalism and its cynical contempt for the human person is besieging everything, all freedoms, all acquired rights? Holistic awareness has brought a positive impact to greater ecological awareness, but followed with scholastic rigor, it stifles reality under the blanket of a determinism that is much more than uncomfortable: all great authoritarian ideologies are holistic. My friend will know how to combine her holistic and transpersonal belief with the freedom and responsibility that each moment asks of us — but how many will make the distinction, under a Law that explains and encompasses everything? How many will abandon themselves to what is? The awareness of the indeterminate brings tragic awareness, as the Greeks knew, but it also brings agency and the courage of decision. And we cannot give up on this. Furthermore, as Drummond shows in the poem “Quadrilha”, by Carlos Drummond de Andrade: «João loved Teresa who loved Raimundo/ who loved Maria who loved Joaquim who loved Lili/ who didn't love anyone./ João went to the United States, Teresa to the convent,/ Raimundo died of a disaster, Maria stayed with her aunt,/ Joaquim committed suicide and Lili married J. Pinto Fernandes/ who had not entered the story.» Real always runs outside the track, completely outside our concepts. That's what matters to us — a J. Pinto Fernandes emerges at the exact moment when we thought we had everything under control.

item.title: From Nobel and others
item.description: 9/10/22 When reading many people's reactions when this year's Nobel Prize for Literature was announced, I couldn't help but remember this comment from Jean-Pierre Siméon, in relation to another Nobel Prize: «An editor of a large national daily newspaper wrote five lines of indignation at the fact that the Nobel Prize for Literature had been awarded to Thomas Traströmer, a complete stranger. But unknown to whom? How did it not occur to this literary columnist, patented and paid to do his job, that his apparent ignorance was a matter of professional misconduct? Tranströmer had been translated into many languages, it was available in French.» There is always the chorus of those who wait for the Prize to be announced to complain about not having been invited to be on the jury, there is a subgroup of angry people who profess “I have never read it and I won’t even bother to read it”; It is a less than humble fauna, the one that inhabits social networks. I don't always know all the winners – I didn't know about the existence of Louise Glück, who I think is a great poet, or Olga Tokarczuk, for example – but this only brings me the comfort of knowing that the world is not a soap opera where everyone knows everyone else and the joy of recognizing that the yardstick of the world is not measured with my short measure and that, on the contrary, it gives me a new opportunity to face the unknown and learn from it. And perhaps the most stupid reaction was that of the intelligent man who wrote, But are there still people who read French?; simply confirming that today there is a new type of ignorance that is being raised with abandon: that of those who only read English. I would also prefer that, in French, Pascal Quignard, Linda Lê or even Sollers were awarded, or, among the new ones, Mathias Énard, but that does not detract from the dignity of Annie Ernaux's work (and it would have been enough to have written “Les Années”). There are books of hers that I like less, like the vulgar “Uma Paixão Simples”, but that happens with almost all authors, they have pivotal books and others that are like breaks in their itinerary. I recommend reading a beautiful book of interviews with her, “L’écriture comme un couteau”. 11/10/22 Yesterday an article appeared in the morning newspaper “Notícias”, in Maputo, reporting that the Pen Club Narrative Prize had been awarded to my wife, Teresa Noronha, for her soap opera “Tornado”, which had already won the Maria Velho da Costa Prize. The summary they made of the book does not even deserve comments, as it is pathetic, but what is important to highlight is the note of disqualification regarding its “Mozambicanness” when they call it Luso-Mozambican. It's not that it's inaccurate, but, for those who know the context, it's a touch naughty. Because finally, following the same logic, Adelino Timóteo should be called Tsonga-Mozambican, Álvaro Taruma Ronga-Mozambican, and Macua-Mozambican for writers from the north, etc., etc. Which doesn't appear to happen. At one point, in the novel, she writes: «Our color was never the dominant one. In colonial times we were not white, we were dressed in monhés, mugs of washed asses, the pejorative term to speak of a son of Goan and Portuguese. In the post-colonial period, I was not black and if, in Lisbon, they took me for Brazilian or Cape Verdean, in France they were lost in thought about where I was from and were surprised when they discovered that I was African. There I had to explain the wanderings of my DNA before settling in Mozambique. It took me a long time to accept that it was like that because yes, and that it was no curse that that was the case; on the contrary, I could even discover intense patterns of fantasy and freedom in this harlequin cloak that is our genealogy…” In modern-day Mozambique, it means being white… and that immediately takes precedence over what you do or what you are. It's sad, but as Naipaul warned, in these parts race is everything and people live as deeply immersed in it as, in other places, in religion. 12/10/22 Bruno Latour, an anthropologist who studied the sciences and their procedures and legitimations, law, technique and religions and who entertained himself by turning his back on the dogmas of the “moderns”, has died. For him, the place, the role of the specialist, was defined more by the perplexity he embodied than by the supposed truth that would sustain him. He proposed, as an alternative to the goodness of multiculturalism and its equivocal cliché “all different, all equal”, a return to “diplomacy”, given that this, precisely, does not start from the assumption that “we are unified because we share the same nature” but simply highlights that we “still do not share a common world”; It is necessary that we deal head-on with the “abyss of disagreement” that separates us, instead of trying to deceive it. And about politics he said, boldly: «If transparency is demanded from politicians, we kill them; if anyone demands fidelity to what the other was or what he says, kill him; If a mimetic relationship is required between what the crowd wants and what its representative says, representation is killed. These must therefore, by definition, betray, deceive, modify, distort the word. Without this ability to bend the word and betray, political language would not exist. I put forward the perfectly plausible hypothesis that political vocabulary will become as inaccessible as the religious language of the last twenty, three or fifty years.» (in “Un Monde Pluriel mais Commun”). I believe we will be needed to decipher this frantically complex world that has fallen to us.

item.title: Fuxi
item.description: O my friends, companions of these disastrous journeys through countries as old as the stars and the Moon, and as strange as the deepest interior of our wretched souls, what surprises still await us, what secret magics will we still have to overcome, what horrors will arise before our pupils dilated with astonishment and terror? Increasingly closer to our precarious existences, howls the monster of war, which threatens to merge humanity once and for all with the earth, incessantly traversed by the squalid specter of hunger and the invisible evil of ten thousand pestilences. Oh damned human, who believes you are superior to Nature itself, but then you reveal yourself, time and time again, incapable of simply ordering your existence and do not understand that you are possessed by fickle anger and are a slave to your own ambition! You are not satisfied with white jade or resplendent gold, there is no treasure that quenches your inextinguishable thirst for command over other men, animals and things; for eternal anguish dwells in you; in you the expelled serpents crawl; for you grows, powerful and impressive, the most fertile ivy of Evil! This is perhaps why on the Mount they call the White Deer, where one of the eight immortals on a sacred mount soared through the heavens towards Penglai, lives the fuxi, a bird whose shape resembles that of a rooster, although topped by a human head. What strange copulations, what monstrous embraces, what terrible procedures must have occurred to make the existence of this sinister animal possible? We don't know, but all it takes is for our exhausted mind to dare to come up with an answer, and then we feel our skin covered in horrendous goosebumps and our heart races in parade, like a wild horse whipped by the night whip of fear, unresponsive to reins and containment. Men should refrain from visiting Monte do Veado, because although there are riches capable of calming the wildest ambitions, if they have the unfortunate luck of catching a glimpse of a fuxi, it is certain that a war will soon break out and the cultivated fields will perish because of it, tame animals will be beheaded, because of it the best young men of two generations will be sacrificed and the land will be destroyed. pride of countries. The fuxi makes a sound reminiscent of its name. If you hear it, dark night or clear day, be on your way, because the path you are on is the surest path to misfortune!

item.title: Procrastinators Club
item.description: While rereading Easter, because of an article I'm preparing, I come across this excerpt, taken from “The Universal Man”: «Each man, morally, is one and absolute; but he has to live with attenuating his personality. (…) Coexistence is only possible between people reduced to a negative or hollow presence, which constantly gives way. Hence, the emptiness of society, an immense ghost made up of countless dead people. A superior man is antisocial or criminal. His destiny is prison and the desert”. I hesitate to think whether Pascoaes reflects here on the political-social conditions that muzzle, and, worse, in a sad country like Portugal in the middle of the Estado Novo (and the book is from 1931) where any possibilities of spontaneity and frankness in human relationships were limited, or if it simply lends to the behavior of (oppressed) men a metaphysical framework, an “essence”, declared in the presumption of each one. to be, in isolation, “one and absolute”. Sometimes, in addition to an excess of Spirituality (or Saudade), Pascoaes lacks the world. He is a great poet, but he is a poet who takes Ampoules-of-Great-Ideas and who therefore writes often trapped by a programmatic furor, ceasing to have pores; It is not uncommon for a glass to be erected between him and reality, the same glass that made him write in O Bailado, from 1921: «Everything is a ghost. There are only clouds, clouds of voices, clouds of souls, of afflictions and tragedies! Clouds and more clouds, appearances and more appearances! And a divine lightning that pierces them, the instantaneous Apparition that appears and throws us to the ground, dazzled!» Sometimes I felt like reminding him, as António Sérgio did, in the article “Regeneration and Tradition, Moral and Economy”, which he dedicated to Pascoaes: «Pascoais, Pascoais my dear friend: you are a pure, excellent and noble poet, but also a victim of this social environment, like us all: of this horrible isolation that you praise and I curse». «As a child, he stole two blackbirds», says Jacinto do Prado Coelho, he stole them from a nest, and he felt remorse for that all his life. The Person, few more mischiefs are known to him. Only in Álvaro de Campos does a hint of wickedness and obscenity emerge: «Ah, and the ordinary and dirty people, who always look the same,/ Who use swear words as usual words,/ Whose sons steal from grocery store doors/ And whose daughters at the age of eight – and I think this is beautiful and I love it! –/ Decent-looking men masturbate in stairwells.” (Triumphal ode). Both poets, driven by a certain idea of ​​sanctity, had the same inability to break the siege of their skin with the overflow of someone else's dam, the same curse of sublimating the concrete ferocity of eros with the gentleness of the verses. Obviously, they are both “bigger than life”, but sometimes it makes me unnerved to watch, from my position as a hatter at the Procrastinators Club, the tantrums between them, just to see who occupies, in the internal organization, the place of President and Treasurer. Although Pessoa guessed more things, for example, what he wrote in the lesser-known Ode Martial and which is reflected in the situation we live in today, in a different way, with his heart in his hands: «MARTIAL ODE (…) Helahoho! helahoho! The poor widow's sewing machine who was bayoneted... She sewed indefinitely in the afternoon… The table where the old people played, Everything mixed, everything mixed with bodies, with blood, All one river, one wave, one dragging horror. Helahoho! helahoho! I unearthed the child's tin train pressed into the middle of the [road, And I cried like all the mothers in the world about the horror of life. My pantheistic feet tripped over the sewing machine [widow who was killed with a bayonet And that poor instrument of peace stuck a spear in my heart. Yes, I was the one to blame for everything, I was the soldier for them all Who killed, raped, burned and broke, It was me and my shame and my remorse like a shadow [deformed They travel around the world like Ashavero, But behind my steps there are footsteps the size of infinity And a physical fear of being accountable to God makes me close my eyes. [eyes suddenly. (…) I ordered, captain, to shoot the trembling peasants, I let the daughters of all fathers tied to trees be raped, Now I saw that it was inside my heart that all this happened, And everything scalds and suffocates and I can't move without it [everything be the same. God have mercy on me, I didn't have it from anyone! LÀ-BAS, JE NE SAIS OÙ…” What is clear today, at this disastrous moment in which Cristiano & Companhia failed in their mission in Braga, and in which the self-sabotage of Russia's gas pipelines reminds us that Putin will indeed be willing to do anything to maintain dominance over the areas endorsed, is that, bomb for bomb, the “bomb” of the Fifth Empire was preferable. However, even in this, my dears, we were irresolute, a little more on the side of piella than determined, and we procrastinated.

item.title: Israel bombs Rafah alleging that Hamas attacked military unit
item.description: Israel launched a series of air strikes against the city of Rafah, in the Gaza Strip, after accusing Hamas of attacking a military engineering unit, security sources cited by the Israeli press said yesterday. Pending an official statement from the Israel Defense Forces and the Islamist group Hamas, military sources confirmed to the Israeli website Walla and the Times of Israel that air and ground attacks had been carried out in Rafah, claiming that it was a response to an attack on an Israeli military excavator tasked with destroying the Islamist organization's tunnels. Although there is still no official information about the existence of deaths or injuries, Israeli military sources told Israeli television that two alleged Hamas militants were killed. It is also unknown whether this crossfire could jeopardize the ceasefire that came into force on October 10, but the Israeli Minister of National Security, Itamar Ben Givr, has already urged the Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, to resume the offensive against the Gaza Strip. “I ask the Prime Minister to order the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) to fully resume fighting in the Gaza Strip with all its personnel,” said the minister, who was convicted in the past for inciting hatred against Palestinians, vandalism and support for terrorism. According to a source from Hamas' armed wing, the group had launched an operation in Rafah to eliminate the leader of the rival militia, known as 'Popular Forces', Yasser Abu Shabab. However, Israeli soldiers intervened to support Shabab, which resulted in crossfire and caused the Israeli excavator to explode. The United States warned on Saturday that it had “credible information” about an “imminent attack” by Hamas against Palestinian civilians, in a “clear violation” of the ceasefire. Chaos installed Yesterday morning, the Islamist group rejected the accusation and blamed Israel for arming and financing other militias, which, it said, carried out “murders, kidnappings, robberies of humanitarian aid trucks and robberies against civilians”. According to Hamas, its members in Gaza are, “with broad civil and popular support”, pursuing these gangs and holding them accountable “according to clear legal mechanisms, to protect citizens and preserve public and private property”. Just one day after the ceasefire, Hamas militants began cracking down on all clans and militias that allegedly collaborated with Israel during the past two years' war, including public executions of alleged collaborators, images of which went viral. The ceasefire in Gaza – proposed by the United States and agreed between Israel and Hamas – has been in force since October 10, providing for three phases: the release of hostages, the disarmament of Hamas and the gradual reconstruction of the territory, under international supervision. The second stage, centered on “demilitarization”, remains the most controversial and the one that Israel considers essential to put an end to the conflict.

item.title: Japan's Liberal Party close to securing new coalition deal
item.description: The Liberal Democratic Party (PLD), in power in Japan, is close to forming a government coalition, which would leave leader Sanae Takaichi just two deputies away from securing election as prime minister. The main Japanese media reported yesterday that the agreement with the Innovation Party of Japan (Ishin) could be closed as early as Monday, the day before parliament meets to choose Shigeru Ishiba's successor. The outgoing prime minister resigned in September from the leadership of the Government and the PLD, which, in primaries held at the beginning of October, chose the conservative and nationalist Takaichi as the candidate to be the first woman to lead Japan. According to the Japanese news agency Kyodo, the PLD and Ishin have agreed to form a coalition without the opposition party guaranteeing seats in the new Government. In return, the PLD would commit to complying with a series of proposals, including reducing the number of deputies, eliminating the tax on food consumption and eliminating political donations from companies and organizations. Today, a final meeting with the PLD is expected. Fragile leadership The newspaper reported that the opposition party is reluctant to occupy positions in Takaichi's possible government and prefers to first ensure that the new PLD leader complies with the terms of the agreement. If elected, the conservative would lead one of the weakest governments in Japan's political history, with a clear minority in both chambers of parliament, which would force her to cooperate with the opposition to pass any law. Ishin's support is essential for Takaichi, especially after the Buddhist party Komeito, with which the PLD was allied for 26 years, abandoned the ruling coalition. The centrist Komeito withdrew from the alliance due to published news about alleged secret PLD funds, having also criticized Sanae Takaichi due to supposed changes in the leader's stance regarding visits to Yasukuni. Diplomatic fears Takaichi, known for her hard-line stance towards China, has visited the Shinto shrine numerous times in the past, especially when she was minister, considered a symbol of the country's militaristic past. But, on Friday, on the first day of the Yasukuni Autumn Festival, 64 years old, he was absent and sent only one offering, because, according to Japanese media, he feared that a visit could upset neighboring countries. Previous visits by senior Japanese officials to the shrine have angered Beijing and Seoul. China and the Korean peninsula were the scene of atrocities committed by the Japanese military in the first half of the 20th century. No sitting Japanese prime minister has visited the shrine in Tokyo since 2013, when Shinzo Abe's visit sparked fury among neighboring countries and rebukes from the United States. The shrine pays tribute to the approximately 2.5 million Japanese soldiers killed in combat, but also to Japanese officers and politicians convicted of war crimes by an international tribunal after World War II. The LDP has governed Japan almost permanently since 1955, despite frequent leadership changes.

item.title: Cambodia | 64 South Koreans deported for criminal practices
item.description: Seoul estimates that around a thousand South Korean citizens are treated as slaves and work in centers in Cambodia dedicated to committing internet fraud. South Korean police confirmed Saturday that Cambodia deported 64 South Korean citizens accused of involvement in centers that practice internet fraud. South Korea sent a team to Cambodia on Wednesday, where it believes around a thousand South Koreans are working in these centers, to discuss dozens of cases of abductions through fraudulent job offers. Seoul then announced, on Friday night, that it was chartering a flight to bring back around 60 citizens, “voluntary and non-voluntary participants” in the fraud schemes, who were detained by the Cambodian police. The group landed on Saturday morning at Incheon Airport, a South Korean police official told the France-Presse news agency. Police authorities were seen preparing to transport them in black security vans. Most of the South Korean returnees were detained in Cambodia during crackdowns on fraud centers and will face police investigations at home, Seoul's national security director Wi Sung-lac said. On Friday, the South Korean government banned South Koreans from traveling to Cambodia, amid an increase in the number of people allegedly abducted by human trafficking networks and organized crime groups based in Cambodia. Criminal groups forced South Korean citizens to commit fraud involving cryptocurrencies via the Internet, in an environment similar to that of a prison. According to diplomatic sources from Seoul and the UN, South Korean citizens are held as slaves and have been subjected to acts of torture by organized crime groups. Seoul's warning also recommends South Korean citizens to leave certain areas of Cambodia. Capital encounters The warning was issued on the day that South Korean Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Kim Jina met with Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Manet in Phnom Penh. The meeting in Cambodia's capital took place after the death of a South Korean student who was allegedly forced to work in a fraud center in Cambodia. Phnom Penh said on Thursday that in recent months it has deported 180 South Korean citizens involved in cybercrime and another 60 are awaiting repatriation. According to a United Nations report, at least 200,000 people are currently held in fraud centers in Cambodia, while in Myanmar (formerly Burma), another epicenter of this phenomenon, the number amounts to around 120,000. Seoul's decision came in the same week that the UK and US governments announced joint sanctions against Cambodia-based conglomerate Prince Group. The president of the group of companies, Chen Zhi, is accused of setting up a cybercrime and human trafficking network.

item.title: Physics | Nobel Prize winner Chen Ning Yang has died
item.description: Chinese physicist Chen Ning Yang, winner of the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1957 and considered one of the most influential researchers of the 20th century in modern physics, died Saturday at the age of 103 in Beijing, Xinhua announced. Chen Ning Yang, born in the eastern Chinese city of Hefei in 1922, received the Nobel Prize in Physics, together with the researcher and his compatriot Tsung Dao Lee, for research into the law of conservation of parity, a fundamental principle of nuclear physics. The two researchers fled China during the war against Japan (1937-1945) and developed their professional careers in the United States, where Chen Ning Yang was a professor at Princeton University and Tsung Dao Lee at Columbia University, when they received the award.
